description: Santa Clauses are pretty interchangeable. The real Santa’s close friend Buddy the elf would disagree, but it’s true: Put on the red costume, hide behind the glossy beard, manage a few ho, ho, hos and anyone will do.

title: Trump Picks Brendan Carr to Lead F.C.C.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Sunday chose Brendan Carr to be chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, naming a veteran Republican regulator who has publicly agreed with the incoming administration’s promises to slash regulation, go after Big Tech and punish TV networks for political bias.

title: Shouting Racial Slurs, Neo-Nazi Marchers Shock Ohio’s Capital
description: Officials in Columbus, Ohio, and across the nation condemned a small group of people who marched through a part of the city on Saturday carrying Nazi flags and shouting racial slurs and expressions of white power.

title: Oregon School Leaders on Leave After 2 Teachers Are Charged With Sex Abuse
description: Two Oregon high school teachers charged on Tuesday with sexually abusing students had been reported as early as 2019 to district officials, who failed to notify the authorities, according to the police.

title: No Corrections: Nov. 18, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, November 18, 2024.

title: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1 Premiere Recap: Sick Burn
description: “Humanity’s greatest weapon is the lie,” says Reverend Mother Tula Harkonnen of the Sisterhood (Olivia Williams). “Human beings rely on lies to survive. We lie to our enemies, we lie to our friends, we lie to ourselves. Lying is among the most sophisticated tasks a brain can perform.”

title: Quote of the Day: How Harris’s Campaign Spent $1.5 Billion in Just 15 Weeks
description: “We had so much money it was hard to get it out the door.”

title: On Migration, Europe Warms to Ideas Once Seen as Fringe
description: Europe has been struggling for years to limit the number of unauthorized migrants entering by land and sea, instituting increasingly tough policies. Those moves now appear to be working, with the numbers of migrants crossing into European Union countries decreasing dramatically from highs last year.

title: Monday Briefing
description: President Biden will allow Ukraine for the first time to use U.S.-supplied long-range missiles to strike deeper inside Russia, U.S. officials said.

title: We’re About to Find Out How Much America’s Leadership Matters
description: The global legal order rests on a kind of collective act of faith. For it to work, nations must trust that other nations will behave as if its principles matter. The system is not so unlike the dollar in this respect: It holds value only when — and only because — most of those who use it believe that it does.

title: ‘The Sex Lives of College Girls,’ Plus 7 Things to Watch on TV this Week
description: Before Reneé Rapp toured sold-out shows or performed songs from her new album on “Saturday Night Live,” she played Leighton Murray, a mean-girl-turned-softy in “The Sex Lives of College Girls.” The show is returning this week for its third season, but Rapp will be absent from most of it — she renegotiated her contract from a series regular to a guest star. It will continue to follow the roommates Kimberly (Pauline Chalamet), Bela (Amrit Kaur) and Whitney (Alyah Chanelle Scott), who left things on rocky footing at the end of the last season. Available to stream at 9 p.m. on Thursday on Max.

title: Word of the Day: gesticulate
description: The word gesticulate has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 30 in “A Veteran Falstaff Looks Back, and Ahead” by Rebecca Schmid. The article includes an interview with Ambrogio Maestri, who has sung the title role in Verdi’s comedy hundreds of times, most recently for the Paris Opera. He’s also making room for a Puccini tragedy. Mr. Maestri states:

title: Emergency Declared as Smog Chokes Parts of India and Pakistan
description: The authorities in New Delhi closed schools and urged people to stay indoors as toxic smog, which has plagued neighboring Pakistan for weeks, choked India’s capital in what officials called a medical emergency.

title: Alan Jones, Former Australian Shock Jock, Charged With Sexual Abuse
description: Alan Jones, a retired controversial Australian talk radio host, was arrested on Monday in Sydney and charged with nearly two dozen counts of sexual abuse.

title: She Moved to New Delhi for a Fresh Start, but the Air Made Her Sick
description: Since moving to New Delhi, which had the world’s worst air quality on Monday, Ameesha Munjal hasn’t been able to exercise or see friends. She has been on several medications to battle sickness caused by the pollution.

title: Will a ‘Trump Bump’ Help the Art Market’s Biggest Week?
description: Will the art market go bananas again, like it did before the pandemic, now that Donald J. Trump has been elected to the White House on promises to cut taxes? Speculative investments like cryptocurrencies have risen in anticipation of a new Republican administration’s anti-regulatory agenda, and the auction world hopes that it can ride an economic boom to recovery after nearly two years of declining sales.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Substack Bets on Politics, With Millions at Stake
description: In April 2023, the newsletter platform Substack received an unexpected proposal from Elon Musk, who had recently purchased Twitter.

title: Will a $9 Congestion-Pricing Toll Yield Enough Money to Fix the Subway?
description: As congestion pricing makes a comeback, there is a lot at stake for New York City’s aging mass transit system.

title: For Decades, Installing E.V. Chargers Didn’t Pay Off for Retailers. Now It Does.
description: Sarajane Leary knows what to do when her electric car is low on power: She goes grocery shopping.

title: José Andrés Hopes to Transform Dining. This Time, at the Airport.
description: Yes, it will offer grab-n-go purchases, specialty cocktails, and plenty of alcoves for suitcases and charging outlets. It is backed by a credit-card issuer, with a world-famous chef attached.

title: Tales of 19th-Century A.I.: Don’t Fall in Love With a Singing Robot
description: Love me, love me, pretend that you love me.

title: 7 Days in the Cultural Life of a Broadway Stage Manager
description: Cody Renard Richard is backstage at the Hudson Theater eight performances a week, wrangling actors and calling cues at “Once Upon a Mattress.”

title: How Healthy Are Sweet Potatoes?
description: The marshmallows notwithstanding, sweet potatoes are one of the healthiest foods on your Thanksgiving table. They’re full of nutrients that keep your systems humming and your blood sugar steady, and they can even reduce your cancer risk.

title: Haruki Murakami’s New Novel Doesn’t Feel All That New
description: When we first meet the nameless narrator of Haruki Murakami’s eerie new novel, “The City and Its Uncertain Walls,” he is a high school loner whose only friend is his cat. A chance meeting at a school awards ceremony brings him into the orbit of an equally isolated eccentric 16-year-old who can’t always distinguish her dreams from real life.

title: New to New York, and Dazzled by the Energy of Times Square
description: When Candice Gwak and David Xie moved from Southern California to New York City, they settled in Hell’s Kitchen, just a block from the chaos and crowds of Times Square, the very place many New Yorkers love to hate.

title: Avengers, Assemble
description: Gail Collins: OK, Bret. Who’s your pick for the worst Trump nomination? I know there’s a lot to choose from — but I’ve got dibs on Matt Gaetz.

title: The ‘Death Becomes Her’ Frenemies Take Their Youth Potion to Broadway
description: To be a marquee name after the ingénue years and to feel validated in a cutthroat business: For many actresses on Broadway or anywhere, those can be constant cravings. For Megan Hilty, one of the stars of the new Broadway musical “Death Becomes Her,” they’re urgent themes.

title: How a Gen X Graphic Novelist Reinvented the Romance Comic
description: To fully understand Charles Burns’s remarkable graphic novel, “Final Cut,” you have to look closely at the way in which it was rendered.

title: The New Anti-Abortion Argument Takes Us Back to the 19th Century
description: Although I’ve heard every argument about abortion, pro and con, over the years, the anti-abortion case made by three Republican-led states in a recent Federal District Court filing stopped me in my tracks.

title: Millennial Pregnancy Gets Its Demi Moore Moment
description: Molly Baz is among the millennial generation’s most influential cooks, and after she became pregnant, she expanded her reach to the care and feeding of parents and babies. In May, she starred in an ad campaign for the breastfeeding startup Swehl, serving up a new recipe for lactation cookies. In one shot, she wore underwear and a rhinestone bikini, presenting an exposed belly and a pair of oatmeal cookies centered with drops of cherry jam, which she held atop her chest as a goofy visual joke. The ad copy said: “Just Add Milk.”

title: Is This the End of the White Working-Class Democrat?
description: In Ohio, Senator Sherrod Brown, a longtime champion of working-class voters, was toppled by a rich Republican former car dealer.

title: Revisiting Pina Bausch’s World of Love and Longing in Aging Bodies
description: Toward the end of Pina Bausch’s “Kontakthof,” a woman stands alone onstage, eyes cast down, disconsolate. One by one, men approach, gently caressing her shoulders, tweaking her nose, stroking her hair, rubbing her legs and stomach. Slowly, the relentless accumulation of these gestures transforms them from affection to assault; tenderness has mutated into aggression, pity into victimization.

title: Why Oil Companies Are Walking Back From Green Energy
description: When oil and gas companies made ambitious commitments four years ago to curb emissions and transition to renewable energy, their businesses were in free fall.

title: How Can I Green Up My Investments?
description: With the world on track for its hottest year in modern history, maybe you’ve decided to invest your money in a way that’s better for the planet.

title: What’s Right and Wrong About Trump’s Defense Secretary Pick
description: Pete Hegseth, like many of President-elect Donald Trump’s cabinet picks so far, may seem unworthy of the role he has been tapped to fill. But the instinct to choose someone like him is not.

title: Venezuela’s ‘Iron Lady’ Pleads With Trump to Save Her Country’s Democracy
description: She galvanized a nation to oust Venezuela’s autocrat at the ballot box, spending months surrounded by people and filling avenues with supporters who risked beatings and arrest just to hear her speak.

title: $2.4 Million Homes in California
description: This property set on 0.44 acres in Topanga Canyon comprises two houses: the main four-bedroom, three-bath house, and a separate one-bedroom, one-bath guesthouse with a living room and kitchen. Trails for hiking and horseback riding link the property to Topanga State Park. A stretch of Topanga Canyon Boulevard with a general store, a pizza shop and a post office is five minutes away, as is Inn of the Seventh Ray, a popular event venue and restaurant specializing in organic food.

title: No, Trump Cannot Run for Re-election Again in 2028
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has mused more than once that he might like to extend his next stay at the White House. But can he run for re-election again in 2028 and seek a third term? The simple answer: No, the Constitution does not allow it.

title: We Can’t Keep Waiting for Our Leaders to Save Us
description: We were living in a cataclysmic age of mass extinction and climate instability even before the election. Now the climate denier in chief is poised to gut the environmental protections that do exist. Even so, conservation nonprofits are struggling to raise the funds they need to challenge his wrecking-ball agenda in court. The people who care are feeling defeated, and the fight has not yet begun.

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, the Northeast Is Burning
description: The smoke around New York City is back. But don’t blame Canada.

title: Hungary Shows Us How a Second Trump Term Might Play Out
description: Donald Trump has referred to Hungary’s autocratic prime minister, Viktor Orban, as “a great man, a great leader.” In this episode of “The Opinions,” the columnist M. Gessen, who is in exile from Vladimir Putin’s Russia, draws parallels between Trump, Orban and Putin. Gessen explores what life might look like in Trump’s next term and describes their fear that, this time, “people are going to retreat into their private lives and try to shut out the political world.”

title: How Do I Decide What Socks to Wear?
description: As far as I am concerned, socks are the underappreciated star of the accessories universe. Handbags get most of the attention, ties and watches a bit, but socks, despite the fact that they are an essential part of everyone’s wardrobe, are often treated as an afterthought, the footwear equivalent of the undershirt.

title: The Fight to Save a Decrepit Pink House by the Sea
description: There is no shortage of beautiful houses along the coastline north of Boston: houses with graceful white columns and gleaming granite stairs. Houses with sparkling bay windows and manicured gardens.

title: A Miniature New York Made of Bark and Acorns
description: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll tour a city within the city, built with acorns and tree bark and other plants. We’ll also get details on the State Department of Labor’s inquiry into Shen Yun Performing Arts.

title: Jake Paul vs. Mike Tyson Is the Absurd Spectacle We Deserve
description: Half the fun of any fight, whether it’s boxing, wrestling or mixed martial arts, is the prefight hype. The opponents call each other terrible names, they glare in each other’s faces at the weigh-in and they appear in a slickly edited video on the Jumbotron as heavy metal music blares — all of it conspiring to persuade everyone involved that this Fight of the Century is going to be even better than the one that took place last month.

title: As Trump Looms, Biden Makes a Twilight Pitch on Ukraine to Global Leaders
description: President Biden began what is likely to be his last summit with global leaders as commander in chief on Monday, pushing for even stronger support of Ukraine despite the looming uncertainty of how President-elect Donald J. Trump might undo his efforts.

title: Spirit Airlines Files for Bankruptcy; Lost $2.2 Billion in 5 Years
description: Spirit Airlines, whose approach to selling cheap tickets without amenities earned it fans and detractors, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday after a string of setbacks, most recently a failure to renegotiate its looming debt.

title: Coffee, Juice, Shawarma: Tiny Traces of Normal Life in a Ruined Gaza
description: At long last, something to celebrate: People were saying that the Chef Warif restaurant, whose Syrian-style shawarma sandwiches were famous in Gaza City before the war, had reopened. Not in the city itself, which the war had reduced largely to rubble. And not the same quality of meat, which the restaurant’s owner now had to buy frozen and at steep prices from traders importing it to the Gaza Strip.

title: Ukraine Has a Window to Strike Within Russia, but Trump May Close It
description: Ukraine signaled a new sense of urgency on Monday following a decision by the Biden administration to allow long-range strikes inside Russia using American-provided missiles, with Ukrainian politicians suggesting that the first launches would come soon and without warning.

title: The Connections Companion No. 527
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: 1 in 8 N.Y.C. Public School Students Was Homeless Last Year
description: When a fire broke out in Jessica Beltran’s Brooklyn apartment last year, she and her two children moved into a homeless shelter while they figured out their next steps.

title: Biden’s Big Shift on Ukraine, and Neo-Nazi Marchers Shock Ohio
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Will Republicans Reject Gaetz?
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has picked Representative Matt Gaetz to be his attorney general.

title: Israeli Strikes in Beirut’s Center Shatter a Tenuous Sense of Security
description: The typically congested streets of Beirut were unusually empty on Monday. Schools that had temporarily shuttered earlier this fall when war first escalated were closed again. Many people who had come back to Lebanon’s capital after fleeing to the northern mountains a month ago had headed north once more.

title: I Tried to Teach My Son Soccer. Here’s What He Taught Me.
description: A few weeks ago, the soccer team that occupies rather more of my thoughts than is healthy had a problem. Well, strictly speaking, it had several. One was that all of the players, including my son, were under the age of 7, which it turns out is something of a tactical limitation. Another was that I had been roped into being one of the coaches.

title: Elon Musk’s Political Influence
description: Over the course of the 2024 presidential campaign, Elon Musk went from dark-money donor to high-profile surrogate to unofficial chief of staff. He camped out at Mar-a-Lago after the election with the Trump family and hopped on Donald Trump’s call with Ukraine’s president. He’s even played diplomat, meeting secretly in New York with Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations.

title: The Race to Lead Trump’s Treasury Dept. Is Becoming a Cliffhanger
description: Few of the unfilled positions in Donald Trump’s cabinet are as important as Treasury secretary. But the question of who will fill the role is only getting cloudier.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,248
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,249
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: What Do You Hope to Get Out of College?
description: Isabella Glassman graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 2023. In her recent guest essay, she writes about the disconnect between what she expected college to be like and what it actually was like:

title: Burglars Broke Into Windsor Castle Estate, Home of Prince William, Kate and Family
description: Intruders broke into the grounds of Windsor Castle last month and stole two vehicles, the police confirmed on Monday, a significant security breach at the sprawling royal estate west of London that is the primary residence of Prince William, his wife Catherine, and their three children.

title: Climate Talks Head Into the Final Stretch With Negotiators Far Apart
description: More than halfway through the United Nations climate talks in Baku, Azerbaijan, negotiators from nearly 200 countries remain far apart on a number of the key issues up for debate.

title: 22 Thanksgiving Dishes Our Recipe Testers Loved This Year
description: At New York Times Cooking, we rely on professional recipe testers to ensure each and every new recipe is clear, works and tastes great. They test about a thousand recipes a year, which is a lot of cooking and eating, so when they really love something, it’s worth taking note. These are a few of the new Thanksgiving recipes that a handful of our testers — Kayla Hoang, Janet McCracken, Lisa Nicklin, Tina Ujlaki and Ben Weiner — couldn’t stop raving about.

title: Texas Education Board to Vote on Bible-Infused Lessons in Public Schools
description: Texas education officials are expected to vote this week on whether to approve a new elementary-school curriculum that infuses teachings on the Bible into reading and language arts lessons.

title: Saudi Arabia Is a ‘Wrecking Ball’ in Global Climate Talks
description: As United Nations climate talks enter their final week in Azerbaijan and G20 leaders gather in Brazil, diplomats from Saudi Arabia, the world’s top oil exporter, are working to foil any agreement that renews a pledge to transition away from fossil fuels, negotiators said.

title: A Mummified Saber-Toothed Kitten Emerges in Siberia
description: In 2020, prospectors seeking mammoth tusks in eastern Siberia found a bundle of fur protruding from the icy bank of the Badyarikha River. The diggers knew they were looking at something rare: the Ice Age mummy of a cat cub.

title: Looters Strip Aid From About 100 Trucks in Gaza, U.N. Agency Says
description: A large convoy of trucks carrying aid was “violently looted” in the Gaza Strip over the weekend and its drivers forced at gunpoint to unload supplies, the main United Nations agency that helps Palestinians said on Monday, calling it one of the worst such incidents of the war.

title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s Views on Vaccination ‘Dangerous,’ Says His Ambassador Cousin
description: Caroline Kennedy, the U.S. ambassador to Australia, said on Monday that her cousin Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s ideas about vaccination were “dangerous” and out of the mainstream.

title: Five-Star, Five-Ingredient Creamy Miso Pasta
description: “So how come you call it midnight pasta when you can’t stay awake past 10?” my daughter asked as I was cooking pasta with garlic, anchovies and red pepper flakes.

title: Park Avenue Armory Will Host Yoko Ono’s ‘Wish Tree’ and Jamie xx
description: The Park Avenue Armory announced its 2025 season on Monday, which includes the North American tour debut for the musician and producer Jamie xx’s new album “In Waves” and the largest ever North American installation of the artist Yoko Ono’s “Wish Tree,” a grove of almost 100 trees that will arrive at the Armory for visitors to attach wishes to.

title: How Will Trump’s Plans Affect the Economy? Here Are 4 Crucial Wild Cards.
description: Predicting how White House policy is going to affect the American economy is always fraught with uncertainty. Donald J. Trump’s return to the White House has taken the doubt up a notch.

title: Elon Musk Asked People to Upload Their Health Data. X Users Obliged.
description: Over the past few weeks, users on X have been submitting X-rays, MRIs, CT scans and other medical images to Grok, the platform’s artificial intelligence chatbot, asking for diagnoses. The reason: Elon Musk, X’s owner, suggested it.

title: Associated Press to Cut Staff by 8%
description: The Associated Press said Monday that it was cutting its staff by 8 percent as part of a plan to adapt to fast-changing conditions in the media industry.

title: Beirut Residents Reel Under Fresh Round of Israeli Airstrikes
description: In the first strikes on Beirut for weeks, at least 10 people were killed and 45 more injured according to Lebanon’s health ministry.

title: Freedom for Scores of Venezuelan Prisoners Detained After Disputed Election
description: From inside a sweltering Tocorón prison on Sunday, the detained peered out at their anguished relatives, throwing kisses from small windows and yelling “Soon!”

title: Trump’s ‘Game of Chicken’ With Appointments
description: To the Editor:

title: How Well Do You Know These Memorable Couples of Literature?
description: Fiction of full of love stories. Try this short quiz on the romantic pairings in five 20th-century novels.

title: Chauffeured Cars and Broadway Tickets: Inside the National Realtors Group
description: When he became the chief executive of the National Association of Realtors seven years ago, Bob Goldberg negotiated a package of gold-plated perks.

title: North Carolina State Supreme Court Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2024 North Carolina state supreme court general election.

title: Quincy Jones Receives Posthumous Oscar, and Daughter Gives His Speech
description: Before his death two weeks ago, the musician and producer Quincy Jones wrote a speech he intended to deliver at the Governors Awards, where he would receive an honorary Oscar at the ceremony created by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Sons Tell of a ‘Devastated’ Family at Rape Trial in France
description: It was not just Gisèle Pelicot’s life that collapsed the day the police delivered the news that they believed that her husband of 50 years had been drugging her and inviting other men into their house to rape her alongside him for almost a decade.

title: Gold Watch, a Gift From Titanic Survivors, Sells for Nearly $2 Million
description: It’s a fine gold Tiffany pocket watch. It probably sold for $20 or $30 when it was first purchased in 1912, and Andrew Aldridge, the managing director of the British auction house Henry Aldridge & Son, guessed that such a watch might normally bring about $10,000 at auction today.

title: Did School Battles Hurt Democrats in Liberal Strongholds?
description: As the election results rolled in on the evening of Nov. 5, the state of Virginia offered an early, alarming portent for Democrats.

title: How Did Fans Dress for Tyler, the Creator’s L.A. Carnival?
description: Over the weekend, Dodger Stadium transformed into a carnival of sorts.

title: Martin O’Malley, Ex-Maryland Governor, Kicks Off Race to Lead D.N.C.
description: Martin O’Malley, the former Maryland governor and Baltimore mayor who for the last year has served as commissioner of the Social Security Administration, on Monday became the first announced candidate for chair of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Yo-Yo Ma and Kathryn Stott Wrap Up a Partnership With Thanks
description: Of all the cellist Yo-Yo Ma’s many, many collaborations, the one with the pianist Kathryn Stott has been among his most enduring.

title: Opponents Renew Attacks as Congestion Pricing Plan Is Approved
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York resurrected congestion pricing last week, delighting transportation and environmental advocates eager for the benefits the plan promises, from less traffic and fresher air to improvements to mass transit.

title: ‘Morning Joe’ Stars Reveal a Mar-a-Lago Reunion With Trump
description: The married MSNBC hosts Mika Brzezinski and Joe Scarborough drove half an hour from their Florida home on Friday to meet with an old friend turned frenemy turned enemy: President-elect Donald J. Trump.

title: What Travelers Should Know About the Spirit Airlines Bankruptcy
description: Spirit Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday after struggling with a series of losses, but travelers should not panic.

title: Trump Confirms Plans to Use the Military to Assist in Mass Deportations
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump confirmed on Monday that he intended to declare a national emergency and use the U.S. military in some form to assist in his plans for mass deportations of undocumented immigrants.

title: Picking Up My Rifle Once More as I Cover Guns in America
description: When I was 9, my dad took me down to my grandfather’s basement. In one corner, the elder Gibbons-Neff had his desk, along with a painting of the submarine-hunting warship he had crewed in World War II and a locked cabinet full of guns.

title: Man Is Charged With Killing 3 in Random Stabbings Across Manhattan
description: It was just before 8:30 a.m. Monday, the police said, when a man approached a construction worker on West 19th Street in Manhattan and, without warning, stabbed him in the gut and ran off. The victim was soon declared dead.

title: Bannon’s New York Trial on Fraud Charges Is Postponed Until February
description: Stephen K. Bannon’s trial on charges that he schemed to defraud people who donated money to build the southern border wall championed by Donald J. Trump was delayed on Monday by a judge in Manhattan.

title: How Elon Musk’s and Vivek Ramaswamy’s Government-Slashing Spree Could Backfire
description: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy are the perfect partners for a president-elect whose signature phrase before his time in the White House was, “You’re fired.” About 80 percent of Twitter’s employees were laid off or quit after Musk bought the social media platform and renamed it X. Ramaswamy said on a September podcast that if the federal government fired 75 percent of its employees, “not a thing” would change “for the ordinary American, other than the size of their government being a lot smaller and more restrained, spending a lot less money to operate it.”

title: SpaceX Starship’s Sonic Boom Creates Risk of Structural Damage, Test Finds
description: SpaceX’s new Starship rocket far exceeds projected maximum noise levels, generating a sonic boom so powerful it risks property damage in the densely populated residential community near its South Texas launch site, new data suggests.

title: Glitz, Glamour and Trash-Talk at the ‘Ultimate Fantasy Competition’
description: It was late Sunday evening at Pullman Yards, a former fertilizer plant and industrial complex that now serves as an entertainment venue on the east side of Atlanta, and the YouTuber Kyle Forgeard’s path to victory in a glammed-up fantasy football championship was narrowing.

title: Veteran Who Was Court Martialed Gets 4 Years in Prison for Jan. 6 Attack
description: A former U.S. Army soldier who was found guilty of voluntary manslaughter in the killing of an Iraqi civilian in 2004 was sentenced on Monday to more than four years in prison for assaulting police officers during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol.

title: How Tulsi Gabbard Became a Favorite of Russia’s State Media
description: In 2017, when she was still a Democratic member of Congress, Tulsi Gabbard traveled to Syria and met the country’s authoritarian president, Bashar al-Assad. She also accused the United States of supporting terrorists there.

title: Tuesday Briefing: Ukraine is Poised to Strike inside Russia
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky suggested that Kyiv’s first launches of long-range weapons inside Russian territory would come soon and without warning. The move signals a new sense of urgency after President Biden’s decision to allow long-range strikes inside Russia using American-provided missiles.

title: Mining Company Whose C.E.O. Was Detained Agrees to Pay Mali $160 Million
description: An Australian mining company said it would pay the military government of Mali $160 million after the authorities detained three of its executives for over a week in a dispute about taxes.

title: ‘Leonardo da Vinci’ Is a Humanizing Look Into a Great Mind
description: “Leonardo da Vinci,” a four-hour, two-part documentary airing on PBS on Monday and Tuesday at 8 p.m. (check local listings), is a thorough and engrossing biography that can’t help but feel incomplete, so vast and unusual is its subject. “Leonardo, for his time, possesses the most knowledge in the world,” one expert explains.

title: Pancreatic Cancer Surge May Be Less Worrisome Than It Seemed
description: One of the first warnings came in a paper published in 2021. There was an unexpected rise in pancreatic cancer among young people in the United States from 2000 to 2018. The illness can be untreatable by the time it is discovered, a death sentence.

title: Biden’s Parting Gift to Ukraine Could Also Help Trump
description: Acceding to Ukraine’s longstanding pleas for permission to fire American missiles into Russian territory may be the last thing President Biden can do for the Ukrainians — or on any other foreign front, for that matter — before leaving office. That makes for dodgy optics, because it saddles an incoming administration with a policy shift Biden himself long resisted because he thought it carried too great a risk of plunging America into a direct confrontation with Russia.

title: Trump’s Signature Dance Move Finds Its Way to the Sports World
description: The first thing to know about the Donald J. Trump dance craze is that it’s not really a craze. (Not yet, at least.) Nor, to be honest, is it a dance.

title: Pennsylvania’s Top Court Tells Counties to Stop Defying Its Ballot Order
description: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court on Monday directed county election officials to stop defying the court’s guidance not to count mail ballots that were missing dates or had errors in the date field on the outer return envelope.

title: Trump Plans to Attend Musk’s SpaceX Launch on Tuesday
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump plans to attend a SpaceX launch in Texas on Tuesday, according to two people familiar with the planning, in yet another demonstration of the billionaire Elon Musk’s increasing closeness to the incoming president.

title: Trump Said He Plans to Use ‘Military Assets’ for Deportations
description: President-elect Donald Trump confirmed today that he intended to declare a national emergency and use the U.S. military to assist in his plans to deport millions of undocumented immigrants. He responded “TRUE!!!” to a post by a conservative activist summarizing the strategy.

title: Morgan Jenness, 72, Dies; Her Artistic Vision Influenced American Theater
description: Morgan Jenness, a dramaturg, teacher and theatrical agent who nurtured the work of countless playwrights — including Taylor Mac, David Adjmi, David Henry Hwang, Larry Kramer and Maria Irene Fornés — died on Nov. 12 in Manhattan. Ms. Jenness, who in recent years began using the pronouns they/them and she interchangeably, was 72.

title: Sandra M. Gilbert, Co-Author of ‘The Madwoman in the Attic,’ Dies at 87
description: Sandra M. Gilbert, a critic, scholar, poet and co-author of “The Madwoman in the Attic: The Woman Writer and the Nineteenth-Century Literary Imagination,” a groundbreaking work of literary criticism that became a feminist classic, died on Nov. 10 in Berkeley, Calif. She was 87.

title: The Governor Who Helped Trump Get Elected
description: It all seemed like a gimmick at first. A chartered bus from Del Rio, Texas, with 24 migrants on board arrived at Union Station in Washington on April 13, 2022. More buses would soon be headed there and elsewhere.

title: Biden Asks Congress for Nearly $100 Billion in Disaster Aid
description: President Biden urged Congress on Monday to provide nearly $100 billion in “urgently needed” aid for communities ravaged by hurricanes and other disasters in recent months, saying funding for some critical programs has either run out or is nearly exhausted.

title: Gaetz May Not Be Confirmed, Trump Admits. He’s Pushing Him and Others Anyway.
description: In his private conversations over the past few days, President-elect Donald J. Trump has admitted that his besieged choice for attorney general, Matt Gaetz, has less than even odds of being confirmed by the Senate.

title: New York City Drought Warning Declared for First Time in Over 20 Years
description: Mayor Eric Adams on Monday elevated New York City’s drought watch to a drought warning, the last step before declaring a drought emergency, which would come with mandatory water restrictions.

title: Instruments of a Beating Heart
description: A look into the Japanese educational system’s delicate balance between teamwork, discipline and personal growth.

title: What a School Performance Shows Us About Japanese Education
description: What makes Japanese people distinctively Japanese? For me, the key lies in what we are taught during our elementary school years.

title: The Dollar Still Has Its Mojo. X, Not So Much.
description: “There is a great deal of ruin in a network,” Adam Smith once observed.

title: Sean Duffy, Fox Stalwart, Gets Trump’s Nod for Transportation Secretary
description: A former Wisconsin congressman and Fox Business host, Sean Duffy, was selected by President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday to lead the Transportation Department.

title: Newsom Will Delay His Decision on Clemency for the Menendez Brothers
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said on Monday that he would not make a decision on granting clemency to Lyle and Erik Menendez, who killed their parents in their Beverly Hills home in 1989, until after the incoming district attorney in Los Angeles County conducted his own review of the case.

title: Arthur Frommer, 95, Dies; His Guidebooks Opened Travel to the Masses
description: Arthur Frommer, who expanded the horizons of postwar Americans and virtually invented the low-budget travel industry with his seminal guidebook, “Europe on 5 Dollars a Day: A Guide to Inexpensive Travel,” which introduced millions to an experience once considered the exclusive domain of the wealthy, died on Monday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 95.

title: N.Y.C. Helped Migrant Accused of Killing Laken Riley Move to Georgia, Witness Says
description: Details of how the Venezuelan migrant charged with killing Laken Riley ended up in Athens, Ga., came into sharper focus on Monday, the second day of a trial that is being closely followed by supporters of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s planned immigration crackdown.

title: Two Bee Gees Drummers Die Within Four Days
description: Two drummers for the Bee Gees — one during the long-running Anglo-Australian pop group’s early days of hit-making ballads, the other during its white-hot disco superstardom — died four days apart, according to posts from a tribute band and former bandmates.

title: Lawyer Says His Client Testified That She Saw Gaetz Having Sex With Underage Girl
description: A lawyer representing two women who testified that former Representative Matt Gaetz paid them for sex told multiple news outlets on Monday that one of the women described witnessing Mr. Gaetz having sex with an underage girl at a party in 2017.

title: Corrections: Nov. 19, 2024
description: An article on Saturday about the possible tension between Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s agenda against Big Food and President-elect Donald J. Trump’s corporate-friendly goals described incorrectly Mr. Kennedy’s recent comments on Froot Loops. He was comparing the total number of ingredients in the U.S. and Canadian versions of the cereal, not the number of artificial ingredients.

title: Dozens of Hong Kong Pro-Democracy Leaders Are Jailed Up to 10 Years
description: Anywhere else, it wouldn’t have been controversial: a public vote by pro-democracy activists trying to strengthen their hand in legislative elections, to decide who should run. More than 600,000 people took part in the peaceful, unofficial poll.

title: Wyoming’s Abortion Bans Are Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
description: A Wyoming judge ruled on Monday that two state abortion bans — including the first state law specifically banning the use of pills for abortion — violated the Wyoming Constitution and could not be enforced.

title: Head Over Heels
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Review: Everyone at the Party Sees Your Texts. A New Play Revels in the Chaos.
description: The script to Robert O’Hara’s new play is prefaced with a trigger warning: “This play is a blistering vulgar satire on Male Toxicity and White Privilege.”

title: Uncertainty for Loved Ones of Hong Kong’s Pro-Democracy Activists
description: Ventus Lau is one of 45 activists and politicians who was sentenced in the city’s biggest national security trial. His girlfriend, Emilia Wong, a gender rights activist, talks about the impact his case has had on their relationship.

title: New Zealand Veers Sharply Right, Leaving Jacinda Ardern’s Era Behind
description: A year before American voters’ anger over the cost of living helped Donald J. Trump win the presidency, similar sentiments in New Zealand thrust in the nation’s most conservative government in decades.

title: Quote of the Day: Beguiling but Bedraggled, A Pink Sentinel by the Sea Gets a Reprieve, for Now
description: “I always saw her as a ballerina, sitting in the marsh alone in her tattered tutu.”

title: Russia Has Suffered Colossal Losses in Ukraine. Is Its Army Depleted?
description: Russia’s military made its largest territorial gains in more than two years in October, as it pressed farther into Ukraine’s eastern Donbas region — but at a heavy cost.

title: The Scandinavian Soft Rock Band That’s Big in Asia
description: They have had the kind of career most bands can only dream of: songs that have been downloaded more than a billion times, 11 million records sold and thousands of fans in dozens of cities.

title: Tuesday Briefing
description: For at least the next two months, Ukraine will be able to try long-range strikes inside Russia using missiles provided by the U.S.

title: Bob Love, Rugged, High-Scoring All-Star for Chicago Bulls, Dies at 81
description: Bob Love, a cornerstone player for the ascendant Chicago Bulls during the first half of the 1970s who overcame an enervating stutter after his playing days to work for the team as a motivational speaker, died on Monday in Chicago. He was 81.

title: Putin Sees America Hurtling to Disaster, With Trump at the Wheel
description: The American election results were received with enthusiasm in Moscow. President Vladimir Putin, offering his congratulations, seemed genuinely pleased. But it’s not because Donald Trump is seen as a pro-Russian politician or even one of their own — those illusions faded long ago. Nor is it the prospect of an advantageous peace deal in Ukraine, ruthlessly brokered by Mr. Trump. The first reported call between the two leaders, which the Kremlin denies took place, suggests that the incoming administration will be no pushover.

title: Word of the Day: mischievous
description: The word mischievous has appeared in 141 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 7 in “Mr. Greedy, Father to Many African Penguins at Maryland Zoo, Dies at 33” by Hank Sanders:

title: Maori Protesters Lead March to New Zealand’s Parliament
description: Protesters dressed in traditional Māori attire performed hakas while marching alongside tens of thousands of people through the streets of the nation’s capital, Wellington, on Tuesday.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Robots Struggle to Match Warehouse Workers on ‘Really Hard’ Jobs
description: In the outbound dock of an Amazon warehouse near Nashville, a robotic arm named Cardinal on a recent day stacked packages, Tetris-style, into six-and-a-half-foot-high carts. Then Proteus, an autonomous platform, moved the carts to the loading bay, flashing electronic eyes designed to make the robot more appealing to human colleagues.

title: Where Glaciers Melt, the Rivers Run Red
description: Dionisia Moreno, a 70-year-old Indigenous farmer, still remembers when Shallap River, nearly 13,000 feet up in the Cordillera Blanca, brought crystal clear water brimming with trout to her village, Jancu. “People and animals alike could drink the water without suffering,” she said. “Now the water is red. No one can drink it.”

title: What to Know About the Daniel Penny Trial as the Prosecution Rests
description: Over eight days of testimony from more than 30 witnesses, prosecutors have not shied away from accounts that described the homeless man whom Daniel Penny choked to death on an F train as frightening. In fact, they sought them out.

title: Teddy Bear Jeans
description: How would you describe your fashion style? Do you tend toward the practical, the traditional and the low-key? Or, do you like to dress in bold, flashy and unconventional designs?

title: An Affordable Housing Project Faced a Huge Backlash. It Won Anyway.
description: This is The Housing Crunch, a five-part series on New York City’s affordable housing crisis.

title: Late Night Is Appalled by Trump’s Mile-High McDonald’s Feast
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: China’s Soaring Emissions Are Upending Climate Politics
description: China has now passed Europe in its historical contribution to global warming. Rich nations say the country should contribute more climate aid.

title: The Man Behind the Legendary Donkey Kong Country Soundtracks
description: The initial hype about Donkey Kong Country, which was released for the Super Nintendo 30 years ago this week, was centered on its impressive 3-D-ish graphics. But the game’s legacy proved to be its soundtrack.

title: Underground, in the Mud, At Sea: A Reporter Goes Far to Cover Energy
description: I cover energy for The New York Times. And you might be surprised by where my beat takes me — from deep inside the earth, as far down as the Empire State Building is tall, to the middle of the Gulf of Mexico on an oil platform that floats 7,000 feet above the ocean floor.

title: Why Do My Ears Hurt on Planes?
description: Q: Sometimes my ears hurt during flights. Why does this happen, and what can I do about it?

title: Kacey Musgraves’s Nashville
description: “I always knew that Nashville would be a destination of some sort for me, that I would land there in terms of music,” said the singer-songwriter Kacey Musgraves during a Zoom call. A native Texan who is nominated for five Grammys this year, including best country album for “Deeper Well,” her fifth studio album, she began singing at a young age and at 18 competed on season five of the country music television show “Nashville Star.” A year later she moved to Nashville and never looked back. “I do owe so much to the community there for absolutely shaping me and my songs, and for giving me the opportunities that I’ve had,” she said.

title: Do You Need to Take Magnesium Supplements?
description: Magnesium supplements are said to help with a long list of ailments: sleep problems, migraine headaches, depression, high blood pressure, muscle cramps, constipation. One wellness coach on TikTok went so far as to say that in order “to be a functioning member of society,” everyone should be taking them.

title: Becoming Cher Didn’t Come Easy
description: Before Twitter morphed into the strange ghost town of X, with lurking users wondering whether to post or stomping off in high dudgeon for Bluesky and Threads, Cher was one of its finest sheriffs. Publications including The New York Times analyzed her grammar-defying style and compiled her stinging critiques of the then and future president Donald J. Trump.

title: 2 Novels Filled With Christmas Miracles
description: If you are a cynical sort (and who isn’t, these days?), the concept of a novel set around Christmas may fill you with a particular squeamishness and fear of holiday cringe. Predictable festive narratives have been fed to many of us throughout our lives, so it’s only fair to feel some wariness.

title: 8 Factors That Put You at Risk of Severe Flu
description: Sore throat. Stuffy nose. Fever, body aches and fatigue. As temperatures drop, cases of the flu have started to rise.

title: How ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Took Gen Z for a Spin
description: The world has changed around “Dancing With the Stars” since the competition series became a hit after its 2005 premiere. Though producers have periodically experimented with casting, canned hosts and tweaked the elimination process, the heart of the show — pairs of professional dancers and celebrities performing weekly and facing elimination based on scores from judges and fan votes — has remained intact.

title: The Artist, the Gallerist and Their Liver
description: Jennifer Doran was in a desperate place on the evening of Feb. 23, 2023, when she quietly interrupted a celebration that Robischon Gallery was throwing for its 45th anniversary and summoned the artists in attendance to join her in a back room.

title: The World Is Watching the U.S. Deal With Bird Flu, and It’s Scary
description: As a virus scientist in South Africa, I’ve been watching with dread as H5N1 bird flu spreads among animals in the United States. The pathogen poses a serious pandemic threat and has been detected in over 500 dairy herds in 15 states — which is probably an undercount. And yet the U.S. response appears inadequate and slow, with too few genomic sequences of H5N1 cases in farm animals made publicly available for scientific review.

title: Robert Frank, a Filmmaker Who Never Stopped Changing
description: In one of art history’s greatest zigzags, Robert Frank, who would have been 100 this year, renounced photography even before he was famous for it.

title: Luigi Nono and the Radical, Urgent Act of Listening
description: In 1954, Arnold Schoenberg’s widow, Gertrud, and their daughter, Nuria, traveled from the United States to Europe for the first time since fleeing Nazism two decades earlier. They went to Hamburg, Germany, for the concert premiere of Schoenberg’s “Moses und Aron,” where Nuria met the young Italian composer Luigi Nono.

title: Ozempic Could Crush the Junk Food Industry. But It Is Fighting Back.
description: Trinian Taylor, a 52-year-old car dealer, pushed his cart through the aisles of a supermarket as I pretended not to follow him. It was a bright August day in Northern California, and I had come to the store to meet Emily Auerbach, a relationship manager at Mattson, a food-innovation firm that creates products for the country’s largest food and beverage companies: McDonald’s and White Castle, PepsiCo and Hostess. Auerbach was trying to understand the shopping behavior of Ozempic users, and Taylor was one of her case studies. She instructed me to stay as close as I could without influencing his route around the store. In her experience of shop-alongs, too much space, or taking photos, would be a red flag for the supermarket higher-ups, who might figure out we were not here to shop. “They’d be like, ‘You need to exit,’” she said.

title: I Liked New York as a Tourist. I Fell In Love With It as a Tour Guide.
description: On a rainy December day in 2022, I did what most New Yorkers loathe to do: I took the train to Times Square. I made my way into a testing center used by the New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection, somewhere between Margaritaville and Madame Tussauds. No, I had not been subpoenaed; rather, I was one multiple-choice test away from becoming a licensed sightseeing guide. All I had to do was answer 150 questions about history, architecture and transit in the five boroughs.

title: 4 Colorful Thanksgiving Veggie Sides to Brighten Your Table
description: The traditional Thanksgiving table generally sticks to a muted, autumnal palette: bland beiges and tans, maybe accentuated by ruddy orange or maroon, and mild flavors to match.

title: Jesse Ed Davis Was Rock Heroes’ Secret Weapon. And a Mystery.
description: In the spring of 1967, the blues singer Taj Mahal was about to cut his first solo album for Columbia Records and needed to find a new guitarist in a hurry. He headed to a bar in Los Angeles’s Topanga Canyon, tipped off about a young Native American musician with a mesmerizing touch on the Telecaster. Having already worked with the guitar prodigy Ry Cooder in the short-lived band the Rising Sons, Mahal had high standards. But it took barely a minute of hearing Jesse Ed Davis to realize he’d found what he was looking for.

title: For Minority Working-Class Voters, Dismay With Democrats Led to Distrust
description: The working-class voters Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign needed were not moved by talk of joy. They were too angry about feeling broke.

title: Jon Batiste Can’t Stop Thinking About Beethoven
description: Long before Jon Batiste was a bandleader, television personality and Grammy- and Academy Award-winning artist, he was a classical piano student.

title: ‘Interior Chinatown’ Puts Stereotypes in the Spotlight
description: One of Jimmy O. Yang’s first TV roles was Asian Teenager No. 2, in a 2013 episode of “Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.”

title: The Hypebeasts Take Las Vegas
description: On the first afternoon of ComplexCon, a head-spinning shoppable trade show, music festival and general meeting of North America’s sneaker zealots, Martin Pawelec stood out in his tucked-in golf polo.

title: Orders for Morning-After Pills and Abortion Pills Rise After Trump’s Election
description: The day after the election, Beth Ryan ordered two packages of emergency contraception pills and had them sent to her 27-year-old daughter.

title: Travel Pledged to Help Cut Carbon Emissions. How Has It Done?
description: In Baku, Azerbaijan, this week, the travel industry will have its first official day ever at the annual United Nations climate talks. At COP29, as this year’s conference is known, Wednesday has been set as a “thematic day on tourism,” and there will be high-level meetings and roundtables devoted to the tourism industry’s effects on the environment and climate change and how they might be mitigated.

title: ‘Les Misérables’ Returns Home
description: Globally, it’s the most famous French musical. One hundred and thirty million people have seen Jean Valjean face off against Javert, in 22 languages; its downtrodden characters have taken to the barricades in London’s West End nearly continuously since 1985.

title: Dan Osborn Wants to Help the Working Class Run for Office
description: Dan Osborn, an industrial mechanic who ran as an independent Senate candidate in Nebraska, came up short in his quest to unseat Senator Deb Fischer, a low-profile Republican whose closer-than-expected victory in a red state clinched Senate control for her party on election night.

title: Ken Martin, a Minnesotan With Deep Democratic Ties, Joins the D.N.C. Race
description: The race for chair of the Democratic National Committee may eventually include candidates who are well known across the party, but few are likely to have deeper relationships with the committee members who have a vote in the contest than Ken Martin, the Minnesota Democratic chairman.

title: Trump Kicks Down the Guardrails
description: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

title: 5 Ways R.F.K. Jr. Could Undermine Lifesaving Childhood Vaccines
description: For years, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., has leveraged his famous name, his celebrity connections and his nonprofit, Children’s Health Defense, to spread misinformation about vaccines and call their safety and efficacy into question. Soon, he might have the power to go much further.

title: Trump’s Win Terrifies Me. Why Don’t Boys My Age Care?
description: Exit polls from the presidential election reveal a divided country: Women tended to vote for Kamala Harris; men, for Donald Trump. And that divide may extend to citizens who aren’t yet of voting age. Naomi Beinart, a 16-year-old junior, witnessed it at her school in the days after the election. In this episode, Beinart says that while her fellow female students fear for the future, “this election didn’t seem to measurably change anything for the boys around me, whether their parents supported Mr. Trump or not.”

title: Magicians Mount Search for Woman Behind Decades-Old Deception
description: The greatest trick that “Raymond Lloyd” may ever have performed was a complex illusion: Convincing an elite, male-only society of magicians that he existed.

title: Wearing Your Personality on Your Handbag
description: It’s easy enough to picture a blue button-up shirt, a pleated mini skirt and ballet flats on a person. Now imagine the outfit on a bag.

title: How to Make Central Park Safer for Pedestrians
description: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out about new recommendations for the roads that loop through Central Park. We’ll also look at data showing that one in eight students in the city’s public school system was homeless last year.

title: Polling Is Not the Problem
description: The polls just can’t win in the court of public opinion — the very thing they’re designed to study.

title: The Connections Companion No. 528
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,250
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Explosive Claims About Gaetz, and Dozens Jailed in Hong Kong Mass Trial
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Editors’ Note
From Resistance to Reflection
description: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

title: Man Drives Car Into Crowd Outside Primary School in China
description: A man drove a car into a group of people near an elementary school in central China on Tuesday, injuring multiple students, in what appeared to be the third large-scale attack in the country in a little over a week.

title: U.K. Farmers Protest in London Over Inheritance Tax Change
description: Thousands of farmers gathered in central London on Tuesday in the biggest show of opposition to a policy announced by Britain’s center-left Labour government since it won power in July.

title: Putin Lowers Russia’s Threshold for Using Nuclear Arms
description: President Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday lowered Russia’s threshold for the use of nuclear weapons, a long-planned move whose timing appeared designed to show the Kremlin could respond aggressively to Ukrainian strikes on Russian territory with American missiles.

title: What’s Killing Kids?
description: If I drew you a graph that showed the death rate among American kids, you would see a backward check mark: Fewer kids died over the last several decades, thanks to everything from leukemia drugs to bicycle helmets. Then, suddenly, came a reversal.

title: U.S. Envoy Signals Progress in Israel-Hezbollah Talks as War Intensifies
description: A top U.S. envoy to the Middle East on Tuesday signaled progress in negotiations between Israel and Hezbollah on a cease-fire proposal that, if agreed upon, could ease hostilities in a region already on edge over Israel’s war in Gaza.

title: Severing of Baltic Sea Cables Was ‘Sabotage,’ Germany Says
description: Germany’s defense minister on Tuesday called the severing of two fiber-optic cables in the Baltic Sea an act of sabotage aimed at European countries that are supporting Ukraine in its war against Russia.

title: What Special Community Rituals and Traditions Does Your Hometown Have?
description: What’s unique or special about your hometown? Are there any community rituals or traditions that bring residents together? Are there annual events that you would recommend to outsiders?

title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Republican Win, Obesity Report, Rhesus Monkeys
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

title: Walmart Sees ‘Momentum’ Ahead of Holiday Shopping Season
description: Walmart has told its workers that it plans to “win” the holiday season. Ahead of the peak shopping period, the nation’s largest retailer appears well positioned, citing “broad-based strength” across its product range.

title: Is the Biden Administration Coming for Chrome?
description: Before the Biden administration’s antitrust leaders step down, they’re taking their final shots at Big Tech. That will reportedly include an effort to break up Google as a consequence of the Justice Department’s successful competition lawsuit against the company.

title: Ukraine Fired U.S.-Made Missiles Into Russia for First Time, Officials Say
description: Ukraine’s military used American-made ballistic missiles on Tuesday to strike into Russia for the first time, according to senior U.S. and Ukrainian officials, just days after President Biden gave permission to do so in a major shift of American policy.

title: ‘Barbenheimer’ Ruled the Box Office. Can ‘Glicked’ Recapture the Magic?
description: The summer of 2023 was all about “Barbenheimer” — when “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” opened the same day, capturing the public imagination and bringing crowds back to movie theaters that had struggled since the pandemic.

title: They Taught A.I. to Sing, and It Was Beautiful
description: Although it’s easy to feel alienated by the opaque processes behind artificial intelligence and fearful that the technology isn’t regulated, the artists Holly Herndon and Mat Dryhurst want you to know that A.I. can be beautiful.

title: Trump, the Military and Plans for Mass Deportation
description: To the Editor:

title: Hacker Is Said to Have Gained Access to File With Damaging Testimony About Gaetz
description: An unidentified hacker has gained access to a computer file shared in a secure link among lawyers whose clients have given damaging testimony related to Matt Gaetz, the former Florida congressman who is President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice to be attorney general, a person with knowledge of the activity said.

title: ‘Excuse Me! How Much Do You Pay for Rent in New York?’
description: Caleb Simpson began his quest to get ordinary New Yorkers to give him a tour of their apartments with an iPhone and a man-on-the-street persona about two years ago. He would spontaneously walk up to random people on the street, asking if they owned or rented their apartment, and how much they paid per month. If they told him — which was rare — he would ask if he could see their home, which he then wanted to post on his social platforms.

title: Trump Defies the #MeToo Movement With Cabinet Picks Facing Accusations
description: When he takes the oath of office in January, Donald J. Trump will make history as the first court-adjudicated sexual abuser to assume the presidency. But if he gets the team of his choice, he will not be the only one in the room whose conduct has been called into question.

title: How Trump’s Tax Cuts and Tariffs Could Turn Into Law
description: Republicans are starting to sketch out how to translate President-elect Donald J. Trump’s economic agenda into law, putting plans in place to bypass Democrats and approve multiple bills reshaping the nation’s tax and spending policies along party lines.

title: As French Rape Trial Nears End, Wife Speaks of ‘Banality’ and ‘Cowardice’
description: For more than 10 weeks, Gisèle Pelicot has sat in a courtroom in Avignon, France, quietly listening to the explanations of 50 men, including her now ex-husband, charged with raping, sexually assaulting or attempting to rape her while she was in an unconscious state, having been drugged by her husband.

title: A Fast, French-y Chicken Dinner
description: What do you cook when you decide to do something nice for yourself for dinner, something a little fancy — or that just feels a little fancy? I know what I’ll be making next time: our new recipe for chicken au poivre, a steakless version of the irresistibly peppery classic. Serve it with egg noodles, a green salad and a bottle of red wine. Be good to yourself! You’re worth it!

title: Delhi Trudges Through Another Air Pollution Nightmare With No Answers
description: On Tuesday morning, the air quality in India’s capital under a widely used index stood at 485. While that is almost five times the threshold for healthy breathing, it felt like a relief: The day before, the reading had shot up to 1,785. Infinitesimal air particles were still clogging lungs and arteries, but it was possible to see sunlight again, and to smell things.

title: Trump’s Treasury Challenge: A Pick Who Loves Tariffs Yet Calms Markets
description: The conflicting goals of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s economic agenda have been playing out as he debates whom to choose as his Treasury secretary, a job that will entail steering tax cuts through Congress, leading trade talks with China and overseeing the $30 trillion U.S. bond market.

title: SpaceX Starship Launch Ends With a Dramatic Water Landing
description: SpaceX’s latest test flight of its Starship vehicle on Tuesday got off to a sobering start, as the company was unable to recover the enormous booster stage of the rocket, the most powerful ever built. But about an hour later, the vehicle’s upper stage was more successful with the completion of a daring maneuver to splash down in the Indian Ocean.

title: The Perfect Novel for the Baku Climate Summit
description: The irony is extreme: This year’s annual United Nations climate change summit is in Baku, Azerbaijan, the petrostate where the modern oil industry was born.

title: Daniel Boulud Opens La Tête d’Or, His First Steakhouse
description: The centerpiece in the plush, bronzed and soaring dining room of Daniel Boulud’s first steakhouse is an impressive two-level grill fueled with charcoal and wood that sits in an open kitchen. Its marble counter frequently bears a display of steaks, from a tomahawk with its flying buttress bone, to compact portions of densely marbled Wagyu, all to be served with choices of butters and sauces. “I’ve always had a steak or two on my menus, but not eight or 10 like here,” Mr. Boulud said. French touches dapple the varied menu that includes sweetbreads, grilled langoustines and sundaes. The 120-seat dining room provides some more intimate areas, including an elegant bar.

title: Lula Was Target of Assassination Plot, Brazilian Police Say
description: Brazilian authorities arrested several members of an elite Brazilian army unit on Tuesday, accusing them of planning to assassinate Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in 2022, shortly before he was to become the country’s president, as part of a plot to keep the far-right incumbent president, Jair Bolsonaro, in power.

title: Disillusioned by the Election, Some Black Women Are Deciding to Rest
description: Cheri Hall woke up hours before dawn the morning after Election Day and checked her phone anxiously for results. A news notification hinting that former President Donald J. Trump had defeated Vice President Kamala Harris caused her to gasp and grab her chest.

title: Manhattan D.A. Suggests Freezing Trump’s Case While He Is President
description: Manhattan prosecutors on Tuesday rebuffed President-elect Donald J. Trump’s request to dismiss his criminal conviction in the wake of his electoral victory, signaling instead their willingness to freeze the case while he holds office.

title: How Thanksgiving Lasagna Became an American Staple
description: Justin Pichetrungsi is having lasagna this Thanksgiving, carrying on a tradition his parents started. But he’ll be making his from scratch. Thanksgiving was a rare day off for his parents, who ran a Thai restaurant, and they weren’t really turkey people. For the holiday, they often bought lasagna from the nearby Costco and served it with the store’s bagged Caesar salad tossed with its packaged Chinese chicken salad dressing. The spread was rounded out with a Cantonese seafood feast from a beloved local restaurant.

title: Texas Education Board Backs Curriculum With Lessons Drawn From Bible
description: Texas education officials backed on Tuesday a new elementary school curriculum that infuses material drawn from the Bible into reading and language arts lessons, a contentious move that would test the limits of religion’s presence in public education.

title: 22 Patrons Stuck for 2 Hours on a Pinwheel Ride in California
description: Twenty-two patrons were stuck in midair for two hours on Monday when a ride broke down at Knott’s Berry Farm in Orange County, Calif.

title: How to Make Your Sofa Look Even More Inviting
description: With sofas, comfort comes first. But a couch typically “occupies prime real estate” in a room, says the decorator Alexandra Pappas, 47, of Pappas Miron Design — meaning it’s worth thinking about its visual appeal, too. Of course, there’s the standard two-pillows-and-a-throw treatment but, for a truly original look, the more colors, shapes and textiles you can incorporate, the better. Take the former Vogue editor Diana Vreeland’s famous Manhattan living room, designed in 1957, where the same red floral fabric covered the walls, curtains and sofa, which was filled with contrasting cushions, including ones that she’d needlepointed herself; or the eclectic Milanese library of the writer and botanist Umberto Pasti, whose couch is strewn with Moroccan carpets and an antique cheetah skin. For practical advice on creating a similarly inviting layered effect, we spoke to a handful of interior designers who have perfected the art.

title: Could Trump Install Gaetz Without Senate Approval? A Recess Appointment Primer.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s rapid move to stock his administration with loyalists, some viewed with skepticism even by members of his own party, is testing both his grip on Senate Republicans and the boundaries of executive power.

title: Nordic Countries, Eyeing Russia, Dust Off Their Crisis Advice
description: The last time that Sweden updated the crisis preparedness advice it distributes nationwide, Russia had not yet launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine and Sweden had not joined NATO in response.

title: A Bizarre Love Triangle Playlist
description: Today’s playlist is all about one of popular music’s favorite shapes: the love triangle.

title: Civil War Toll Much Worse in Confederate States, New Estimates Show
description: Faded ink. Inconsistencies. Fires. The deadliest conflict in American history, the Civil War, also had some of its worst-kept records, making the true number of casualties seem forever elusive.

title: Inching Toward a Fusion Energy Future
description: In 1952, a machine with a funny name and a funny shape was zapped to life in the mountains of New Mexico. The Perhapsatron, a doughnut-shaped glass tube surrounded by magnets, was one of the world’s first nuclear fusion devices. Its name reflected the feelings of its creator, James Tuck, a scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory: “Perhaps it will work and perhaps it won’t.”

title: Trump Taps Wall St. Executive Howard Lutnick for Commerce Secretary
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump picked Howard Lutnick to serve as commerce secretary on Tuesday, tapping a billionaire Wall Street executive for one of the most prominent and increasingly powerful economic positions in the federal government.

title: Vehicle Hits Students Outside Elementary School in Central China
description: A man drove a car into a group of people near an elementary school in Changde, a city in Hunan Province, on Tuesday, injuring multiple students.

title: TKTS to Open Booth in Philadelphia, Hoping to Boost Local Theaters
description: TKTS, the landmark theater discounter that has been a Times Square mainstay for 51 years, is expanding to Philadelphia at a time when regional theaters are struggling and ticket costs are a persistent cause of consumer concern.

title: Did the Trump Prosecutions Damage Democratic Credibility?
description: On election eve in Philadelphia, Oprah Winfrey issued this warning to a rally full of Kamala Harris supporters: “If we don’t show up tomorrow, it is entirely possible that we will not have the opportunity to ever cast a ballot again.” Winfrey was once one of the most trusted figures in American public life. And yet most voters did not believe her. The next day, Donald Trump won the popular vote.

title: Unexpected Turns in Trump Election Cases Raise Questions About Their Durability
description: Election interference cases against President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies are moving forward in Georgia and Arizona, but recent complications in each case have fueled speculation about whether the prosecutions are in more fragile shape than they were before Mr. Trump won the election.

title: ‘Tammy Faye’ Musical to Close After Failing to Find Broadway Audience
description: “Tammy Faye,” a new musical about the scandal-wracked singing televangelist, will close on Broadway after an unexpectedly short run, a major disappointment for a costly and ambitious show that picked up some good reviews in London but was poorly received in New York and failed to find an audience.

title: Richard V. Allen, Reagan’s First National Security Adviser, Dies at 88
description: Richard V. Allen, President Ronald Reagan’s first national security adviser, who was forced to resign after less than a year in office, much of it under a cloud of controversies that muted his voice in contributing to foreign and military policies, died on Saturday in Denver. He was 88.

title: Trump to Watch Latest SpaceX Launch With Elon Musk
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump is traveling to Brownsville, Texas, on Tuesday to attend a test launch of SpaceX’s next-generation rocket in another show of solidarity with Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, who helped catapult the former president back to the White House.

title: Son of Norway’s Crown Princess Is Arrested on Suspicion of Rape
description: The eldest son of Norway’s crown princess was arrested on suspicion of rape on Monday, the authorities in Oslo said, the latest accusation in a scandal that has roiled the country’s royal family.

title: How Trump Can Earn a Place in History That He Did Not Expect
description: Does Donald Trump’s return to the presidency herald the end of U.S. pressure on Israelis and Palestinians for a two-state solution? Not necessarily: It depends on which Donald Trump occupies the White House.

title: For Russia, Nuclear Weapons Are the Ultimate Bargaining Chip
description: On the 1,000th day of the war in Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky took advantage of Washington’s new willingness to allow long-range missiles to be shot deep into Russia. Until this weekend, President Biden had declined to allow such strikes using American weapons, out of fear they could prompt World War III.

title: House Republicans Target McBride With Capitol Bathroom Bill
description: When Representative-elect Sarah McBride, a Delaware Democrat, won her race for the House this month, becoming the first openly transgender person elected to Congress, she knew she would face attacks from hard-right Republicans over her identity.

title: Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine hits Russia with U.S. Missiles
description: Ukraine’s military used American-made ballistic weapons known as ATACMS yesterday to strike into Russia for the first time and hit an ammunition depot in the Bryansk region of southwestern Russia, officials said.

title: Asheville Gets Drinkable Tap Water Back, 53 Days After Hurricane Helene
description: Jeff Watts, 57, barely followed the incremental updates on his city’s water distribution system after Hurricane Helene knocked it offline in September. All he knew was that life in Asheville, N.C., had become more difficult and dirty.

title: At 17, She Just Passed the State Bar of California
description: Sophia Park, 17, and her family huddled around her laptop one evening this month as she entered her details onto the State Bar of California’s website and clicked “Check pass list.”

title: Physicist Who Made Superconductor Claims Exits University of Rochester
description: Ranga Dias, a physicist who faced a public reckoning over accusations of research misconduct, is no longer employed by the University of Rochester, a spokeswoman for the institution said Tuesday.

title: Trump Plans to Nominate Dr. Mehmet Oz to Oversee Medicare, Medicaid and Obamacare
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that he would nominate Dr. Mehmet Oz, the author and former television host, to serve as the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, a powerful agency that oversees health insurance programs covering more than 150 million Americans.

title: The Onion’s Bid to Acquire Infowars Has Gotten Messy
description: There was a merry triumphalism to the announcement last week that The Onion, a satirical outlet based in Chicago, won an auction to acquire the conspiracy site Infowars out of bankruptcy.

title: A Nostalgic Biden Fades Out of the Picture in Talks With World Leaders
description: World leaders at the Museum of Modern Art in Rio de Janeiro were discussing plans to confront poverty and war when President Biden acknowledged the obvious — this was most likely his last time attending such an elite meeting.

title: Two Apartment Buildings Were Planned. Only One Went Up. What Happened?
description: New York City is dealing with its worst housing shortage in decades. The diverging fates of two developments offer a window into the crisis.

title: Sean Combs’s Lawyers Argue That Seizure of Notes From Jail Was Unjust
description: Sean Combs appeared in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday as his lawyers objected to the prosecution’s use of handwritten notes found inside the music mogul’s jail cell, arguing that his rights had been violated when they were turned over to prosecutors.

title: Ukraine Fired U.S.-Made Missiles into Russia
description: Early this morning, Ukraine’s military launched a volley of American-made ballistic missiles into Russia for the first time. The attack came on the 1,000th day of the war and less than a week after President Biden gave the Ukrainians permission to do so in a major shift of American policy.

title: House Race in California Is Separated by 314 Votes
description: The contest between Representative Michelle Steel, Republican of California, and her Democratic challenger, Derek Tran, has become the tightest House race in the country, with margins hovering for days in the dozens of votes.

title: Netanyahu Offers $5 Million for Each Hostage Freed in Gaza
description: Cease-fire talks to end the fighting in Gaza are stalled. Casualties in the enclave are mounting. And the families of hostages captured from Israel in the Hamas-led attack that ignited the war have grown increasingly desperate about the plight of their relatives in captivity.

title: Atmospheric River and Hurricane-Strength Storm Drenches the West
description: A historically strong storm system with the strength of a hurricane whipped damaging winds through the Pacific Northwest overnight leading to power outages across the region. It was creating large ocean waves and ushering in a drenching atmospheric river that is expected to continue soaking Northern California.

title: As Elon Musk Moved to the Right, His Businesses Moved to Texas
description: Elon Musk had long been drifting away from the political culture of California, railing against its regulations and pandemic-era lockdowns. So, four years ago, he decided to move to Texas, eager to embrace its wide-open business culture and be embraced by its Republican leaders.

title: Democrats Face a Series of Tests Over Support for Israel
description: Democrats whose support for Israel has been strained by the wars in Gaza and Lebanon appear headed for a series of tests in the coming weeks over continuing to back Israel’s right-wing government and the attendant debate over antisemitism and the anti-Israel left.

title: Defining Deviancy Down. And Down. And Down.
