description: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Friday that he would nominate Dr. Martin A. Makary, a Johns Hopkins University surgeon with a contrarian streak, to be commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Florida’s Top Health Official Urges an End to Putting Fluoride in Water
description: Florida’s surgeon general issued guidance on Friday that called for a halt to adding fluoride to the water supply, backing a similar push by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Emerging Details of Chinese Hack Leave U.S. Officials Increasingly Concerned
description: Leaders of the top telecommunications companies were summoned to the White House on Friday to discuss a security problem that has been roiling the government: how to expel Chinese hackers from the deepest corners of the nation’s communications networks.

title: Israel Is Not an I.C.C. Member. How Can the Court Prosecute Israeli Leaders?
description: The arrest warrants issued this week by the International Criminal Court for leaders of Israel and Hamas, for crimes it accuses them of committing in Gaza, offer important insights into both the extent of the court’s jurisdiction and the limits of its power.

title: Labor Secretary Pick Is Rep. Lori Chavez-DeRemer of Oregon
description: Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a first-term Republican representative from Oregon who narrowly lost her House seat this month, was chosen on Friday to serve as labor secretary in the coming Trump administration.

title: Trump Chooses Dr. David Weldon, a Former Congressman, to Lead the C.D.C.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump chose Dr. David Weldon, a former congressman, on Friday to serve as the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Reacts Like a Superfan
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Ryan McCarty is in a group of constructors whose work almost always appears on Saturdays: This is his 24th such grid, and his fifth in a row. Mr. McCarty also specializes in variations on the chunky pattern we have here, which is challenging to solve because its dense patches are connected only by an entry or two. You can be grooving nicely on one corner, thinking it’s a walk in the park, and next thing you’re stranded on an island of empty squares without a helpful crossing entry in sight.

title: Alice Brock, Restaurant Owner Made Famous by a Song, Dies at 83
description: Alice Brock, whose eatery in western Massachusetts was immortalized as the place where “you can get anything you want” in Arlo Guthrie’s 1967 antiwar song “Alice’s Restaurant,” died on Thursday in Wellfleet, Mass. — just a week before Thanksgiving, the holiday during which the rambling story at the center of the song takes place. She was 83.

title: Sebastian Gorka to Return to White House as Adviser
description: Sebastian Gorka, the firebrand conservative commentator who worked in the White House briefly in President-elect Donald J. Trump’s first term, was named by Mr. Trump on Friday to a senior advisory position.

title: Why the Rain Won’t End the Drought in the Northeast
description: Hundreds of brush fires and wildfires have sparked all over the New York City region. Hilary Howard, who covers climate change and the environment in the region, explains what’s happening.

title: Trump Picks Scott Turner, Little-Known Official From First Term, to Lead HUD
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has chosen Scott Turner, a little-known former pro football player and motivational speaker, to lead the Department of Housing and Urban Development, an agency that plays a central role in addressing the growing national affordability crisis.

title: Ex-N.Y.P.D. Officer Convicted of Sex Offenses Involving 4 Underage Boys
description: A former New York City police officer was convicted on Friday of sex offenses involving four underage boys, including a robbery victim whom he befriended and then preyed on over Snapchat by sending him an explicit photo and asking for one in return.

title: A Lesson From Poland: Reversing Populist Policies Is Tough
description: He promised salvation for a country “in ruins” — an end to immigration, a civil service stripped of entrenched left-wing opponents, a judiciary purged of meddlesome judges and a news media giving voice to the people instead of elites.

title: Cash, Kidnappings and Luxury Resorts: A Formula for Power in Modi’s India
description: The lawmakers had finished a routine assembly vote and were scattering into the Mumbai night.

title: 55 Days Into Hunger Strike, Activist’s Mother Says She ‘Won’t Back Down’
description: After a few days without food, the hunger stops. The body, while weak, “learns how to just function.” That is how Laila Soueif, an Egyptian mathematician and professor, describes her hunger strike, which reached 55 days on Saturday.

title: Quote of the Day: Nothing Short of Perfection Will Do
description: “I could argue that I’m having more of an impact on people here than I could have anywhere else. But personally — personally — I want to go play for a national championship.”

title: As Threat of Trump Tariffs Looms, Europe’s Leaders Seek Greater Unity
description: For months, European business leaders have watched as Donald J. Trump paved a path back to the White House by doubling down on an “America First” economic policy, putting protectionism and business-friendly tax and regulatory pledges high on the agenda.

title: Corrections: Nov. 23, 2024
description: An article this weekend on Page 10 about late-night host Johnny Carson incorrectly quoted part of a line from a famous Johnny Carson quip. The joke goes, “Half the marriages end in divorce — and then there are the unhappy ones,” not “and then there are the happy ones.”

title: Trump Chooses New York Doctor to Be Next U.S. Surgeon General
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Friday selected Dr. Janette Nesheiwat, a New York medical director with family ties to his first administration and a Fox News contributor, to be the next surgeon general of the United States.

title: One Dead in U.S. Listeria Outbreak Tied to Ready-to-Eat Meat and Poultry
description: A baby died and at least 10 other people in four states fell ill in an outbreak of listeria tied to ready-to-eat meat and poultry products sold by Yu Shang Food, federal health officials said on Friday, as the company recalled more than 72,000 pounds of items.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: How a Pop Pianist Spends Her Sundays
description: Chloe Flower first came to New York City when she was 12. She was with her parents, and she had one question for them: “Why didn’t you bring me sooner?”

title: Can the Gilgo Beach Suspect’s House Become a ‘Nice Starter Home’?
description: Neighbors breathed a sigh of relief this week when an empty shipping container appeared outside the dilapidated red house in Massapequa Park that has become known as the home of the accused Long Island serial killer.

title: Dining Sheds Changed the N.Y.C. Food Scene. Now Watch Them Disappear.
description: Street side sheds and shanties helped keep restaurants afloat during the worst of the coronavirus pandemic. Now, for better or worse, new city rules are forcing their removal.

title: F.B.I. Agents Investigate Use of Fake Donors in N.Y. Assembly Race
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have opened a criminal investigation of Dao Yin, a recent New York State Assembly candidate suspected of using fake donors and forged signatures to artificially inflate his allotment of matching funds, according to several people familiar with the matter.

title: Israeli Strike in the Heart of Beirut Kills at Least 20
description: An Israeli airstrike on a residential building in central Beirut killed at least 20 people on Saturday, the Lebanese Health Ministry said, part of an intensifying Israeli military campaign that appears aimed at pressuring Hezbollah into a cease-fire deal.

title: How to Focus Like Your Life Depends on It
description: Most of us don’t require F1-level focus to get through our days. But we all struggle with distraction — and the techniques that drivers use to optimize their performance can help anyone to be more intentional and effective in all sorts of situations. We asked McLaren Formula 1 team driver Oscar Piastri (that’s him, in the video above), along with a sports psychologist and an attention expert, for tricks to stay on track.

title: An ‘Enhanced’ Version of the Olympics May Happen. Should It?
description: On a recent morning this fall, Aron D’Souza was at home in London expecting a long-anticipated delivery: a vintage set of the “Great Books of the Western World,” a collection with over 50 volumes of philosophy, history and literature published in the 1950s by Encyclopaedia Britannica, including “Faust,” Freud’s “On Narcissism” and “The Hippocratic Oath.”

title: How Brunch Came to a Backyard Farm in Compton
description: On the first and third Sunday of every month, Alma Backyard Farms hosts brunch. Long, elegant folding tables are set up between raised beds packed with dinosaur kale, collards and beans. Butterflies weave around sage.

title: Trump’s Trade Agenda Could Benefit Friends and Punish Rivals
description: The sweeping tariffs that President-elect Donald J. Trump imposed in his first term on foreign metals, machinery, clothing and other products were intended to have maximum impact around the world. They sought to shutter foreign factories, rework international supply chains and force companies to make big investments in the United States.

title: Want a Diamond? You’ll Need to Decide on Lab-Grown or Natural.
description: With Thanksgiving marking the unofficial start of engagement season — late November through Valentine’s Day is when marriage proposals are common — ring buying is top of mind for many couples considering marriage.

title: They Investigated Pandemic Fraud, Then Earned Thousands
description: When J. Bryan Quesenberry first learned that the federal government was sending out hundreds of billions of dollars to help businesses survive during the Covid-19 pandemic, he thought: “There’s going to be fraud here. There just has to be.”

title: Lucy Liu Thinks It’s Important to Make a Mess Sometimes
description: Lucy Liu’s 9-year-old son, Rockwell, hasn’t seen his mother draw blood in “Charlie’s Angels” or “Shazam! Fury of the Gods” and certainly not in “Kill Bill, Vol. 1.”

title: Stratford-Upon-Lake-Michigan: Royal Shakespeare Company Plays Chicago
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company, which keeps the plays of William Shakespeare alive in the town of his birth, was long a regular presence in the United States. It brought Ian McKellen to Brooklyn as King Lear, built a replica of its main theater in an Upper East Side drill hall and sent a stream of shows to Broadway.

title: I’m Ending My Lease Early and Found the Landlord a New Tenant. Can He Refuse?
description: Q: I’m moving out of my rent-stabilized apartment in Brooklyn and I provided my landlord with a suitable replacement, a friend of a friend who needs a new place after ending a relationship. When I told my landlord that I needed to end my lease early and that I had a replacement for him, he responded that it would be fine as long as she worked with his broker. His broker is charging a large fee and asking for a guarantor that makes 80 times the rent. Is 80 times the rent typical? And why would she have to pay a broker’s fee here?

title: The French Philosopher Whose Romantic Theory of Time Was All the Rage
description: In the second decade of the last century, The New York Times could not stop writing about Henri Bergson, whom it called “the favorite philosopher of the salons.” There was a gushing interview from Paris, in which the great man explained “his wonderful philosophy of the ‘vital impulse’ working in and through matter.” There were reviews of books by him and about him. A cable from Rome relayed the pope’s condemnation of his “poisonous” errors. A report from uptown counted over a thousand guests at a tea party in his honor at Columbia University. And when Bergson tried to slip quietly into the country in 1917, that, too, was headline news: “French Philosopher Comes on the Liner New York Unheralded.”

title: Chasing the Perfect Photograph in Amish Country
description: In his mug shot, the photographer George Steinmetz doesn’t seem especially threatening. It captures some of the inquisitive humanity that Steinmetz, a tall and direct people’s person with a John Malkovich mien, conveys in life.

title: The Surprising Impact of North Carolina’s New Voter ID Law
description: After more than a decade of court battles and legislative jousting over voting rules, North Carolina this month held its first general election under its new voter ID law.

title: Hezbollah Believed to Be Using Copy of Israeli Missile Against Israel
description: The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah has been using an advanced missile against Israel that was reverse-engineered from an Israeli weapon it captured in a past war, according to Israeli defense officials.

title: She Faked a Religious Conversion to Escape Terrorists
description: For more than six years, Alice Loksha Ngaddah bided her time, waiting for an opportunity to escape her abductors.

title: Election Forecasts Try to Go Beyond the Polls. Are They Helping?
description: In 2008, Nate Silver’s election forecast model was so novel — and accurate — that it landed him on Time magazine’s list of the 100 most influential people the next year.

title: The Supervillain Is the Hero Now
description: On Election Day, Elon Musk posted a video on X, his social media platform, presenting himself as an avatar of “Dark MAGA.” A blizzard of pop-culture memes evoking anime, comic books and action movies, the two-minute supercut bristles with a familiar chaotic energy. Donald Trump, in his trademark blue suit and red tie, strides across the frame in broad daylight, while Musk, in a black cap and T-shirt, cuts a gleefully diabolical figure. To date, the video has garnered 91.4 million views.

title: Can Disney Cut Into Netflix’s Stand-Up Comedy Dominance?
description: Spend some time in the comedy world and you will hear complaints about Netflix, which has established itself as the most important home for stand-up for nearly a decade.

title: Hundreds More Nazca Lines Emerge in Peru’s Desert
description: Gouged into a barren stretch of pampa in southern Peru, the Nazca Lines are one of archaeology’s most perplexing mysteries. On the floor of the coastal desert, the shallow markings look like simple furrows. But from the air, hundreds of feet up, they morph into trapezoids, spirals and zigzags in some locations, and stylized hummingbirds and spiders in others. There is even a cat with the tail of a fish. Thousands of lines jump cliffs and traverse ravines without changing course; the longest is bullet-straight and extends for more than 15 miles.

title: What Trump’s Cabinet Picks Tell Us About His Second Term
description: President-elect Donald Trump is filling key cabinet positions with controversial picks at a breakneck speed. Jonathan Swan, senior political correspondent at The Times, explains why these choices are significant, even if they don’t all make it into office.

title: Republicans Ponder: What if the Trump Tax Cuts Cost Nothing?
description: What counts as a tax cut?

title: Trump Promised to Halve Energy Costs in 18 Months. Experts Have Doubts.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump repeatedly promised voters that he would cut energy and electricity prices in half within 18 months of taking office.

title: I Tested the Latest FAFSA. It Works Fine. Don’t Celebrate Yet.
description: Last year, in a fit of masochism, I tried to become the first person in the United States to fill out a FAFSA (short for Free Application for Federal Student Aid) form at the precise moment the Department of Education unveiled a long-delayed overhaul.

title: On Blood-Soaked Ground, a ‘Prayer for the Future’ of a Divided Land
description: The bugler’s call to assemble had sounded, wreaths had been laid, a choral society had sung and dignitaries had spoken, all on a blood-consecrated hill in the Pennsylvania town of Gettysburg. All to commemorate the 161st anniversary of the speech that came to epitomize what it meant to be presidential.

title: A Long-Held Secret Is Now Public. Will It Alter Cormac McCarthy’s Legacy?
description: This week, Vanity Fair published a bombshell article revealing that Cormac McCarthy, one of the country’s most celebrated and enigmatic novelists, had a relationship with a girl he met when he was 42 and she was 16, a foster child who felt so unsafe at home she often carried a gun and used the pool area at the motel where he was staying to shower.

title: The Voice of Milhouse on Saying Goodbye to ‘The Simpsons’
description: When you answer your phone to hear a grown woman shouting “Wazzzuuuuup?” in the voice of a 10-year-old boy, you can be pretty sure that you’re talking with Pamela Hayden. For some 35 years, Hayden has played many distinctive characters on “The Simpsons,” the long-running animated Fox sitcom, but none with more nerdy exuberance than Milhouse Van Houten, the hapless but good-hearted best friend of Bart Simpson.

title: With Memes and in State Media, Many Russians Cheer on Putin’s Threats
description: The day after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia raised the stakes in tensions with the West, many Russians awoke on Friday feeling anxious that the prospect of nuclear war had come slightly closer.

title: Trump Won More of New York’s Votes. Did He Win More of Its Love, Too?
description: Even though Donald J. Trump is cloistered in Florida and planning his return to Washington, it seems like he has been stuck in a New York state of mind.

title: An Idaho County Will Publish Everyone’s Ballots to Combat Mistrust
description: In the aftermath of the 2020 election, as supporters of Donald J. Trump scoured the nation for any malfeasance that might explain his defeat, the county clerk’s office in Boise, Idaho, was inundated with queries.

title: Kayaker Trapped on Australian River Has Leg Amputated in 20-Hour Rescue
description: A kayaker’s leg was amputated on Saturday in a harrowing 20-hour effort to free him after he became trapped in rocks on a river in Australia, the police in the state of Tasmania said.

title: K-Pop Trained Rosé to Be ‘a Perfect Girl.’ Now She’s Trying to Be Herself.
description: South Korean pop, known as K-pop, is not just a type of music — it’s a culture, where bold style, perfectly choreographed dance moves and ebullient earworms that draw from pop, hip-hop and traditional Korean music attract a huge and particularly devoted global fan base. The genre’s stars, known as idols, are trained, often for years, by entertainment companies that then place the most promising trainees in groups, write and produce their music and obsessively manage their public images. It’s a system that works for the idols who make it big, but it has also drawn criticism for its grueling methods, which some call exploitative.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,254
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 532
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Alberta Breaks With the Canadian Pension Model
description: Without any advance notice, the government of Alberta last week fired all 10 directors on the board of its pension fund, Alberta Investment Management Corporation, along with its chief executive and three of his most senior employees. Then, this week, it announced that Stephen Harper, the former Conservative prime minister, would serve as the fund’s chairman.

title: Your Heart’s Desire
description: It’s “Glicked” weekend, if you’re up for it, an invitation to take in a double feature of two of the season’s most anticipated movies, both of which opened yesterday: “Wicked,” Jon M. Chu’s adaptation of the Broadway musical, starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande, and “Gladiator II,” Ridley Scott’s return to the Colosseum 24 years after his original epic.

title: No Grandchildren in Their Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Gift Ideas That Push Back the Darkness
description: This column is part of Times Opinion’s 2024 Giving Guide. Read more about the guide in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

title: The Bizarro Normalcy of the Public Reaction to Trump’s Win
description: One of the things that has been clear with Donald Trump’s win this time is how different it is: no shock wave jolting society. This is, according to polling, one of the presidential election outcomes most widely accepted as legitimate of the past 25 years. The reaction from some of those who didn’t vote for him seems more restrained, with a widespread interest in preservation of self amid potential chaos — a retreat from the news to focus on family, friends and peace of mind.

title: Three Theories of the Trump Cabinet
description: Before Donald Trump’s victory, making detailed predictions about how his second administration would govern seemed like a fool’s errand — there were too many multitudes within the Trumpian tent, too many promiscuous promises to voters, to say for sure what forms of Trumpism would end up expressed in a second four-year whirl.

title: Trump: Protector of Women — or Predators?
description: Donald Trump proclaimed that he would be the protector of women.

title: No One Was Worried About My Country’s Elections This Year. They Should Be.
description: In a year of landmark elections, my country’s presidential vote last month flew under the radar. And perhaps with good reason: Uruguay’s balloting was marked by unexciting candidates and their lackluster attempts to entice undecided voters to the polls. In the end, no candidate won a majority, leaving weary Uruguayans to brace for another round of unimpressive speeches leading up to a runoff on Sunday.

title: Gladiator Movies Aren’t Telling the Real Story About Rome
description: For a modern audience, it’s tempting to valorize the Roman gladiator — strong, brave, fierce — as a masculine ideal. Indeed, ancient Rome has become for many young men an exemplar of a “lost” masculinity, as evidenced by the social media accounts and TikTok posts celebrating Roman culture. For that crowd, “Gladiator II,” the blockbuster movie that arrived on Friday, with its arena battles and bloody clashes between sword-wielding warriors (and occasional live sharks), will be a welcome moment to celebrate a Roman notion of manly individualism. There’s just one catch: To ancient Romans, gladiators were not ideals of masculinity, or of heroism.

title: They Hate Each Other. They Love Each Other. We Can’t Look Away.
description: When Glinda and Elphaba, the leads of the new movie adaptation of “Wicked,” clap eyes on each other, it’s loathe at first sight.

title: Sectarian Violence Kills at Least 25 in Northwest Pakistan
description: Violent clashes erupted overnight between Sunni and Shiite tribes in northwestern Pakistan, leaving at least 25 people dead and markets, homes and government properties in flames, officials and residents said on Saturday.

title: 2 Books for Readers Who Don’t Care About Polite Company
description: Dear readers,

title: Biden’s Chief Economist Processes the Election With ‘Confusion, Guilt’
description: Since the election, Jared Bernstein, the chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, has often found himself in a down mood — dealing, he says, with “confusion, guilt” and “cognitive dissonance.”

title: Stock for Sale by Cabinet Members
description: As President-elect Donald Trump takes an unconventional approach to stocking his cabinet, he’s also embracing one candidate pool that has plenty of precedent: Wall Street chief executives.

title: Where You Should Donate This Holiday Season
description: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning and on Saturdays.

title: So Many Days Lost at the Doctor’s Office
description: Deana Hendrickson sometimes feels daunted by the demands of the medical system. “Every body part has a doctor,” she lamented. “I hate it.”

title: Hot Take: Pumpkin Pie Is Good
description: I’ll come right out and say it: I love pumpkin pie. I know this seasonal treat has its detractors, but it’s only because they’ve never had a good pumpkin pie. And I get it. A wan pumpkin pie — one without enough spiced oomph in its filling and a bland, stodgy crust — is just an aboveground pool of sugary squash mush.

title: Food Poisoning Kills 23 Children as South Africa Declares Emergency
description: The six young children had just shared  snacks bought from a corner store when they began convulsing. The children, all of them under 8, died moments later, adding more victims to a wave of food poisoning that the authorities say has killed nearly two dozen children in a few months.

title: How Scott Bessent Went From Democratic Donor to Trump Treasury Secretary Pick
description: In the heat of the 2000 presidential campaign, Vice President Al Gore took a break from barnstorming battleground states to attend a fund-raiser for the Democratic National Committee in East Hampton, N.Y. Standing behind Mr. Gore onstage was Scott Bessent, a hedge fund manager and — at the time — a major donor to Democrats who co-hosted the event at his home.

title: Blue Man Group to End New York Run After Three Decades Off Broadway
description: Blue Man Group, the wordless theatrical troupe of drum-beating, paint-splattering, bald blue performers, will end its run in New York on Feb. 2, more than three decades and 17,000 performances after it began.

title: Down About the Election? There Is a Speech I Want You to Read.
description: Most Americans who know of Frederick Douglass know that he lived to see the destruction of chattel slavery and the liberation of Black Americans from the despotism of human bondage. Less well known is the fact that Douglass would also live long enough to see the slave stand free, stand a brief moment in the sun, and move back again toward slavery, to paraphrase W.E.B. Du Bois in his book “Black Reconstruction.”

title: What’s Behind Ukraine and Russia’s Missile Brinkmanship?
description: The low-lying clouds over the city lit up for a split second, video footage showed, then streaks of dozens of glowing warheads plummeted out of the sky.

title: Madeleine Riffaud, ‘the Girl Who Saved Paris,’ Dies at 100
description: Madeleine Riffaud, a French Resistance hero who survived three weeks of torture as a teenager and who went on to celebrate her 20th birthday by helping to capture 80 Nazis on an armored supply train, died on Nov. 6 at her home in Paris. She was 100.

title: Israeli Strike Hits Residential Building in Central Beirut
description: At least 20 people were killed and dozens of others were wounded in the strike on Beirut’s Basta neighborhood.

title: Scenes From the Storm That Drenched the West Coast
description: A gusty, rain-soaked storm swept through the Pacific Northwest and Northern California this week, killing at least three people and knocking out power for hundreds of thousands of customers.

title: 2-Year-Old Gorilla Dies After Being Struck by Hydraulic Door at Zoo
description: A 2-year-old gorilla died of traumatic injuries last week at the Calgary Zoo in Alberta, Canada, after being struck by a hydraulic door that a staff member mistakenly activated, according to the zoo.

title: Shape Up or Ship Out
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

title: Trump Picks Brooke Rollins, a Conservative Lawyer, to Lead Agriculture Dept.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Saturday chose Brooke Rollins, his former White House domestic policy adviser, to helm the Agriculture Department, whose wide-ranging purview includes supporting farmers who grow the nation’s two biggest crops, corn and soybeans, and setting the nutrition standards in school cafeterias across the nation.

title: Climate Talks End With a Bitter Fight and a Deal on Money
description: Negotiators at this year’s United Nations climate summit struck an agreement early on Sunday in Baku, Azerbaijan, to triple the flow of money to help developing countries adopt cleaner energy and cope with the effects of climate change. Under the deal, wealthy nations pledged to reach $300 billion per year in support by 2035, up from a current target of $100 billion.

title: California Educator Is Charged With Molesting 8 Children
description: A Los Angeles assistant principal was arrested on Friday and charged with molesting eight children between 2015 and 2019, while he was working as an elementary school counselor in Ventura County.

title: Owners of Colorado Funeral Home Admit to Abusing Nearly 200 Corpses
description: A couple who owned a funeral home at two locations in Colorado pleaded guilty on Friday to multiple counts of corpse abuse, more than a year after 191 bodies were found decaying at their businesses in a horrific scene, the authorities said.

title: Trump’s Choices for Health Agencies Suggest a Shake-Up Is Coming
description: A longtime leader of the anti-vaccine movement. A highly credentialed surgeon. A seven-term Florida congressman. A Fox News contributor with her own line of vitamins.

title: Corrections: Nov. 24, 2024
description: An article this weekend on Page 10 about late-night host Johnny Carson incorrectly quoted part of a line from a famous Johnny Carson quip. The joke goes, “Half the marriages end in divorce — and then there are the unhappy ones,” not “and then there are the happy ones.”

title: Fred R. Harris, Oklahoma Senator Who Ran for President, Dies at 94
description: Fred R. Harris, a maverick Oklahoma Democrat who served eight years in the Senate and who lost a race for his party’s 1976 presidential nomination in a populist campaign that challenged politics as usual and proposed radical changes for America, died on Saturday in Albuquerque. He was 94.

title: Tortured, Burned, Put to Death. Their Crime? ‘Sorcery.’
description: The men came wielding bush knives. They wanted to avenge a baby girl, who had died the night before. They said she had been killed by a sorcerer’s black magic, and accused a woman who had encountered the baby that morning.

title: A Corruption Case That Spilled Across Latin America Is Coming Undone
description: One of the largest corruption crackdowns in recent history is being quietly wiped away.

title: What Two Acclaimed Female-Directed Movies Say About Indian Cinema
description: One is a deft comedy about the misadventures of two young brides in rural India. The other is a delicate tale about the intersecting lives of three women in cosmopolitan Mumbai.

title: Taking a Second Look at the Lives of Troubled Girls, a Decade Later
description: I remember the first day that the photographer Ruth Fremson and I met the Lady Jaguars, a misfit basketball team of troubled teens in West Tennessee. It was winter, 13 years ago. The girls, ages 13 to 17, were tossed together because a juvenile-court judge sentenced them to a strict day school called Carroll Academy. They never came close to winning games.

title: Quote of the Day: Bathing in Oil Might Seem Crude Near a Climate Summit, but Locals Swear by It
description: “The resin itself is a bit toxic. But for skin problems, the resin really helps.”

title: What Ever Happened to the Lady Jaguars?
description: Her name is Hannah. When I met her more than a decade ago, she was a wide-eyed and curious seventh grader with church-pew manners. She was chatty and clingy, a dreamer with a trusting heart. She played with dolls and sang in a choir. She wanted to be a veterinarian and live in a mansion.

title: The Democrats Are in Trouble. This Man Can Save Them.
description: The election victory by Donald Trump and his Republican Party was a rebuke of a Democratic Party that has positioned itself as protector of a despised status quo, rendering it unable to connect with an electorate desperate for change. Defeating Mr. Trump in the future will require liberals, progressives and others on the left to articulate a positive vision that can capture the imagination of a broad majority of Americans.

title: Taiwan Is Ready to Defend Democracy. Is Trump?
description: I don’t envy American voters. Your presidential choices have an impact halfway across the planet. Your soldiers fight and die in other countries’ wars. I know you’re tired of feeling you have to fix the world’s problems. But like it or not, this unique privilege and responsibility comes with being a citizen of the greatest country in the world.

title: New York City Hotel Rates Soar to Record Heights as Holiday Travel Nears
description: For a recent Friday night at a Hilton in Times Square: $537, including a daily $35 “destination charge.”

title: Chinatown Vendor Tallies Neighborhood’s Decline in $1 Plastic Bracelets
description: By the time Shaohua Yu erected his stand at around 10 a.m., Chinatown was already bustling. Tourists were wandering around the stalls along Canal Street, where Chinese peddlers and recent immigrants from Africa were selling the same fake Louis Vuitton and Gucci products. Behind Mr. Yu, the New Kam Man supermarket had just rolled up its steel curtain. A row of roasted ducks hung in the window facing him.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Trash Talk at Work? Uncool in Any Language.
description: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

title: ‘Every Few Pages Reflected Each Person’s Take on Their Experience ’
description: Dear Diary:

title: At Bible Study for the Homeless, a Search for Meaning
description: Six mornings a week, a call for quiet stills a day center for homeless people in Northern Virginia, and those so inclined gather to thank God, read scripture and ponder its message for their tribulations.

title: Former Obama Aide Enters the New York City Mayor’s Race
description: Michael Blake, a former New York State assemblyman from the Bronx and a veteran of the Obama administration, is entering the crowded race to unseat Mayor Eric Adams.

title: Have New York’s Football Teams Finally Hit Rock Bottom?
description: Misery and gloom are haunting the Giants yet again this football season. But there is one consolation: At least they aren’t the Jets.

title: An Israeli Rabbi Is Abducted and Killed in the U.A.E.
description: An Israeli rabbi in the United Arab Emirates who had been missing since Thursday has been found murdered, Israeli and Emirati authorities announced on Sunday. Israeli officials called the death of the rabbi, Zvi Kogan, an act of terrorism, without providing any further details.

title: Reading, With Extra Cheese: Remembering Pizza Hut’s ‘Book It!’
description: It was late one night last spring, and I was Googling cultural phenomena that would mark milestone anniversaries in 2024, as a sleepless reporter does.

title: In West Bank Raids, Palestinians See Echoes of Israel’s Gaza War
description: The Israeli soldiers grabbed his arms on each side, Nasir Damaj recalled, marching him through the streets to the blown-out shell of a mosque.

title: Should You Still Learn to Code in an A.I. World?
description: When Florencio Rendon was laid off from his third construction job in three years, he said, “it was the straw that broke the camel’s back.”

title: Shopping and Shame Share the Shelves in ‘American Bulk’
description: We have reached peak feedback. The customer is not only always right, but always writing, rating. The bank, the phone company and the hospital want us to evaluate our experiences with them on a scale of 1 to 10. There are Yelp reviews of Planet Earth.

title: A Survivor in Spain Filmed How the Water Flooded Her Town in Hours
description: Rosalía Arenas, a resident of Utiel, recorded on her phone for nearly five hours as deadly floods submerged her street. A boat eventually evacuated Ms. Arena and her 2-year-old child.

title: Raging Waters Were Headed Their Way. Why Did Nobody Tell Them?
description: Hours before a river of mud descended on towns around Valencia, trapping and killing hundreds of people, water started gushing through the small Spanish municipality of Utiel.

title: The Icy, Terrifying, Pathological Human Need to Climb
description: In 1519, the Spanish conquistador Diego de Ordaz reached the summit of the stratovolcano Popocatépetl during an expedition in Mexico under Hernan Cortés.

title: A Reggaeton Ode to Colombia Is a Hit, but It’s Not Music to Everyone’s Ears
description: “A mamacita since she was 14,” the song says in Spanish, with a chorus that repeats: “And even though that little baby has an owner, she goes out whenever she wants.”

title: ‘Wicked’ and ‘Gladiator II’ Jump-Start the Box Office, but at a Cost
description: Hollywood was back this weekend to where it desperately hungers to be — at the center of global culture.

title: How Southwest Airlines Lost Its Groove
description: Three years ago, Southwest Airlines started flying out of Bellingham, Wash., a growing city near the Canadian border, aiming to do what it had done in dozens of smaller airports — sell lots of tickets to people who have few other travel options.

title: Shopping for a Good Riding Boot?
description: Riding boots are worn today as much for walking on city sidewalks as they are for hunting or the other horseback activities for which the footwear was originally made centuries ago. But with so many options out there, how does one choose?

title: The Amsterdam Attacks and the Long Shadow of ‘Pogroms’
description: Femke Halsema, the mayor of Amsterdam, may have touched off a diplomatic incident last week when she said on a Dutch television show that she regretted having used the word “pogrom” the day after attacks on Israelis in her city surrounding a soccer match.

title: Immigrants Across U.S. Rush to Prepare for Trump Crackdown
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has vowed to slash immigration — both legal and illegal — and ramp up deportations on Day 1.

title: ‘Shoot Me Up With Everything’
description: Vaccines are an indispensable news gathering tool. They permit reporters to travel to areas where fatal or debilitating diseases are prevalent; exactly the places that warrant coverage by The New York Times.

title: Trump Is Running His Transition Team on Secret Money
description: Updated Nov. 27: Since this article was published, an aide to President-elect Donald J. Trump said that although Mr. Trump’s transition did not plan to sign an agreement with the General Services Administration, it would not accept donations from foreigners and would disclose donors’ names. The aide did not say when Mr. Trump would release those names or if he would limit the size of donations to $5,000, as previous president-elects have.

title: Egypt Feuds With Travel Blogger, Issuing 1,100-Word Response to Complaints
description: Authoritarian governments are not known for taking kindly to criticism. And in Egypt, official skins can be especially thin: Deepening repression has muffled most dissent and sent tens of thousands of perceived political opponents to jail, including one for posting a doctored photo of the president with Mickey Mouse ears.

title: ‘A God Who Continually Surprises Us’: A Q&A With a Theologian Who Changed His Mind About Gay Marriage
description: I’ve spent my life in politics, but faith has been most central to shaping who I am. My conversations with people of faith have been among the most enriching of my life. Richard Hays, an ordained minister who is an emeritus professor at Duke Divinity School, is one of the world’s leading New Testament theologians. In 1996 he wrote “The Moral Vision of the New Testament,” in which he argued that gay and lesbian sexual relationships distort God’s created order and that churches should not bless same-sex unions. In his new book, “The Widening of God’s Mercy,” written with his son Christopher Hays, Richard Hays says he was wrong. I spoke to Richard Hays about his journey and what changed his mind. This conversation, which has been lightly edited, is the first of what I hope will be a series exploring the world of faith.

title: Donald Trump Thinks He Won’t Have Enough Power
description: These are the times that try a constitutional conservative’s soul.

title: The Connections Companion No. 533
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,255
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: There’s a Simple Way to Stop Dangerous Wildfires. We Barely Use It.
description: The Northeast didn’t see it coming, but suddenly we are putting out a lot of wildfires: The state of New York is in the midst of its most active wildfire season in more than a decade. A wildfire in southwestern Massachusetts grew to 1,000 acres this week, the second fire in the region to reach that size this month. New Jersey has suppressed 500 wildfires and counting this fall.

title: Hezbollah Fires About 250 Projectiles Into Israel After Deadly Strike in Beirut
description: Hezbollah fired about 250 projectiles into Israel on Sunday, a day after an Israeli strike in the heart of the Lebanese capital killed more than 25 people.

title: New Thanksgiving Classics
description: The menus are being planned, grocery lists made, details finalized — it’s nearly go time for Thanksgiving, a time for epic feasting and the one day of the year on which even the most reluctant home cooks wander into the kitchen. Are you ready?

title: I Starred in ‘Cabaret.’ We Need to Heed Its Warning.
description: This past week marked 58 years since the opening night for the Broadway premiere of “Cabaret” in 1966. At the time, the country was in deep turmoil. Overseas, the Vietnam War was escalating, and at home, our most regressive forces were counterpunching against the progress demanded by the civil rights movement. The composer John Kander, the lyricist Fred Ebb and the playwright Joe Masteroff wrote “Cabaret” in collaboration with the director Harold Prince as a response to the era. The parallels between the rise of fascism in 1930s Berlin as depicted in the show and the mounting tensions of the 1960s in America were both obvious and ominous.

title: Connecticut Couple Charged in $1 Million Theft of Lululemon Goods
description: A Connecticut couple were charged with being part of an organized retail theft operation that is suspected of stealing about $1 million in Lululemon merchandise across several states, the authorities said.

title: Former BP Chief Joins A.I. Data Center Developer
description: Bernard Looney, the former chief executive of BP, one of the world’s largest energy companies, said Sunday that he would become chairman of a data center start-up in the United States, a move that comes amid a ravenous appetite for electricity to power the boom in artificial intelligence.

title: Fat, Flaky Mounds of Quick Bread, Golden Brown, With a Significant Crumb
description: Good morning. This is going to be a long week, even if you love Thanksgiving unreservedly.

title: Getting the Election Wrong, and Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Without Drama or Banana, Art Auctions Struggle
description: Despite auctioneers selling about 1,600 works of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art within the last week, the only serious moment of excitement came from a $6.2 million banana. The conceptual artwork, “Comedian” by Maurizio Cattelan, had a crowd of at least 300 jammed into the Sotheby’s salesroom to witness its absurd triumph — becoming the world’s most expensive fruit in a series of sales where several more traditional artworks failed to muster even a single bid.

title: Chuck Woolery, Host of ‘Love Connection,’ Dies at 83
description: Chuck Woolery, who was the affable host of “Love Connection,” “Wheel of Fortune” and other television game shows and who later criticized liberal values and the Democratic Party as the co-host of a popular right-wing podcast, died on Saturday at his home in Horseshoe Bay, Texas. He was 83.

title: Does the Conductor Klaus Mäkelä Deserve His Meteoric Rise?
description: A raucously received performance of Mahler’s First Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Saturday was the latest exclamation point in the conductor Klaus Mäkelä’s meteoric rise. Mäkelä is just 28 and made his Carnegie debut a mere eight months ago with the Orchestre de Paris — one of the two very good ensembles he currently leads.

title: 2 Dead After Civil Air Patrol Plane Crashes in Colorado Mountains
description: Two people died and one was injured after a Civil Air Patrol plane crashed while conducting an aerial photography training exercise amid the rugged peaks of Larimer County, Colo., on Saturday, officials said.

title: Rico Carty, Exceptional Hitter Who Was Stymied by Injuries, Dies at 85
description: Rico Carty, a Dominican baseball star whose early exceptional promise was thwarted by untimely injuries, died on Saturday. He was 85.

title: What to Know About Brooke Rollins, Trump’s Choice for Agriculture Secretary
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump rounded out his cabinet selections on Saturday, picking Brooke Rollins as his agriculture secretary.

title: The World Seeks an End to Plastic Pollution at Talks in South Korea
description: On the heels of contentious climate talks in Azerbaijan, negotiators from around the globe are descending on Busan, South Korea, this week with another formidable goal: the world’s first treaty designed to tackle plastic pollution’s explosive growth.

title: Hezbollah Fires About 250 Projectiles Into Israel
description: Hezbollah’s attack came after Israel’s deadly strike on Beirut on Saturday. It was one of the largest mounted by the militant group against Israel since it started firing on the country last year in solidarity with Hamas.

title: Charles Dumont, Who Wrote Enduring Melodies for Édith Piaf, Dies at 95
description: Charles Dumont, who wrote the music for “Non, Je Ne Regrette Rien,” the soaring song about sweeping away the past to find love anew that the hallowed but troubled singer Édith Piaf turned into an anthem of French culture, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Paris. He was 95.

title: Tony Campolo, Preacher Who Challenged Religious Right, Dies at 89
description: The Rev. Tony Campolo, one of the most influential evangelical preachers of the past half century, who urged Christians to resist the strong political tug of the religious right and to affirm that their faith called them, first and foremost, to fight poverty and racism, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 89.

title: Trump’s Cabinet: Many Ideologies Behind the Veil of ‘America First’
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s final flurry of cabinet picks and other appointments rounded out what his aides described as a unified, loyal, MAGA-driven administration. But scratch the surface and there are at least three distinct factions and a range of ideologies, barely suppressed to get through the rigors of the confirmation process.

title: Dartmouth Sorority and 2 Fraternity Members Are Charged After Student’s Drowning
description: A Dartmouth College sorority and two fraternity members have been charged with underage alcohol offenses in the death of a 20-year-old student who drowned after attending an off-campus party this summer.

title: Monday Briefing: U.N. Climate Talks End With a Deal
description: Negotiators at this year’s United Nations climate summit, known as COP29, struck an agreement early yesterday to help developing countries adopt cleaner energy and cope with the effects of climate change. Under the deal, wealthy nations pledged to reach $300 billion per year in support by 2035, up from a current target of $100 billion.

title: Israel Conducts Widespread Strikes Near Beirut
description: The Israeli military late on Sunday conducted a heavy barrage of airstrikes on the southern outskirts of Beirut where Hezbollah holds sway, with fighter jets racing across the skies above the Lebanese capital and deafening explosions ringing out for miles.

title: Nations at COP29 Climate Summit Agree to Annual $300 Billion Pledge
description: Delegates from developing countries described the deal’s financial target, $300 billion per year by 2035, as lacking the ambition needed to help their governments combat climate change.

title: Perches in a Coop
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Washington Curtails Intel’s Chip Grant After Company Stumbles
description: The Biden administration plans to reduce Intel’s preliminary $8.5 billion federal CHIPS grant, a move that follows the California-based company’s investment delays and broader business struggles.

title: The Official Unofficial Record
description: On This Week’s Episode:

title: No Corrections: Nov. 25, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Uruguay’s Center Left Reclaims Power in Presidential Election
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — A onetime mayor and history teacher defeated the candidate of the conservative coalition that has governed Uruguay for the past five years to win his country’s presidency on Sunday.

title: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1, Episode 2 Recap: The Agony
description: Desmond Hart is an anomaly. He is alive after a sandworm attack that should have left him in the belly of the beast. He knows of the Sisterhood’s secret plan to play puppet master with the universe’s rulers as their marionettes. He can burn people to death using only his mind, apparently from light years away. He can resist the Voice, with which Mother Superior Valya Harkonnen has subdued even other powerful members of her own Sisterhood.

title: Quotation of the Day: The Jets and Giants Take Different Routes Toward Rock Bottom
description: “I had a feeling this year might not go very well, and now it’s like I’m a NASCAR fan waiting to see the wreck.”

title: Monday Briefing
description: Negotiators at this year’s U.N. climate summit, known as COP29, struck an agreement early yesterday to help developing countries adopt cleaner energy and cope with the effects of climate change. Under the deal, wealthy nations pledged to reach $300 billion per year in support by 2035, increased from the current target of $100 billion.

title: Don’t Let Donald Trump Drive You Into Internal Exile
description: Since Donald Trump’s victory, I have not been able to stop thinking about Vladimir Putin’s return to the Russian presidency in 2012 — another time in which an exhausted populace found itself unclear on what to do next.

title: Your Thanksgiving Day Watching Lineup, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: Whether you’re big on cooking, big on eating or big on avoiding Thanksgiving altogether, one of the best parts of the holiday is that there are endless options on TV throughout the day.

title: DHL Cargo Plane Crashes Near Airport in Lithuania, Killing 1
description: A DHL cargo plane crashed in a residential area near Vilnius Airport in Lithuania, killing one person on board and setting a house ablaze, officials said.

title: Word of the Day: saturnine
description: The word saturnine has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 29 in “For This Goth, Halloween Is Her Christmas” by Marisa Meltzer:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: As New York’s Migrant Crisis Eases, Trump’s Deportation Threat Looms
description: After a two-year influx of asylum seekers, New York City leaders are cautiously optimistic that the migrant crisis has begun to subside.

title: Ultranationalist Leads First Round of Romania’s Presidential Election
description: Romania, a NATO member and host to a missile defense facility built by the United States, has been thrown into political disarray by the surprise victory of a little-known ultranationalist in the first round of a presidential election held this weekend.

title: ‘Everyone Thought We Were Going to Die’: Living With Flight Trauma
description: Last January, Shandy Brewer boarded an Alaska Airlines flight from Portland, Ore., to Ontario, Calif., en route to her grandmother’s birthday celebration. She was seated in the 11th row, between her father and a stranger. Shortly after takeoff, Ms. Brewer and the other passengers heard a loud bang. She couldn’t see that 15 rows behind her one of the plane’s doors had blown off, exposing passengers to open air at 16,000 feet.

title: How Healthy Is Turkey?
description: Americans gobble up more than 46 million turkeys on Thanksgiving, according to some estimates. But experts say that this love for the bird shouldn’t end when the holiday is over. Eating turkey regularly — whether it’s sliced in a deli sandwich or ground up in chili — can boost your health in more ways than one.

title: Great Apes and Tiny Bears: Chasing Wild Thrills in Borneo
description: We lurched along an unpaved road in the night, walls of trees and knotted vines on either side. In the darkness lurked some of the world’s most unusual mammals, and I had come to Borneo to fulfill a lifelong dream to see them: catlike civets, scaled anteaters called pangolins and big-eyed colugos that spread their body flat as they glide from trunk to trunk.

title: The Teeny, Tiny Tee Is Back (Again)
description: Lauren Caruso had never really bought into the idea of dressing for one’s body type. “It’s incredibly limiting,” she said, adding that the concept is really just code for wanting “to look thinner or taller or attempt to reinforce other Eurocentric beauty standards.”

title: Should I Sit Through the Movie’s Closing Credits?
description: Do you have a question for our culture writers and editors? Ask us here.

title: Kyle Abraham Is Fully in His Feelings About Now
description: In rehearsals, the choreographer Kyle Abraham is usually at the front of the room, directing and shaping his work. But on a recent afternoon at the Park Avenue Armory, he came running into the studio with childlike abandon — the opening of his latest dance.

title: 10 Picture Books That Help Kids (and Adults) Celebrate Gratitude
description: “Practice gratitude.” It’s a simple instruction we see on tote bags, coffee mugs and yoga T-shirts. And just like yoga, we know that, when we do it, we will feel better. Yet it can often feel nearly impossible to maintain this habit. Is it any wonder why? Even in this season of abundance, there are plenty of bona fide reasons to cry, complain and kvetch! Just remember: Our kids are listening. Build back your gratitude muscle by sharing these 10 picture books with the little ones in your life. I promise you’ll be thankful that you did.

title: Why Some of the Year’s Best Performances Are From Actresses Who Say Very Little
description: IN A TENSE moment midway through Edward Berger’s recent movie “Conclave,” a pulpy thriller about the process of selecting a new pope, Isabella Rossellini, playing a nun named Sister Agnes, enters a room full of cardinals from around the world. A series of uncovered secrets and shifting alliances have turned this initially serene council into a rat’s nest of backstabbing, grandstanding, explaining, interrupting men. After asking permission to speak, Sister Agnes discreetly delivers a piece of information that will upend the papal election and expose some of the most powerful figures in the Roman Catholic Church to public, career-ending humiliation. Her short speech concluded, she bobs at the waist ever so slightly, giving a tiny curtsy whose performance of feminine deference is a put-down in itself. For the rest of the film, Sister Agnes never says another word.

title: Black and White Clothes That Are Surprisingly Festive
What’s Wrong With White Bread?
description: ON A RECENT Tuesday, all the diners at the New York raw bar Penny, with its marble counter, cream-colored brickwork and ice boxes of escabeche mussels and fresh shrimp, had come seeking sophistication. So why was there so much white bread? Nearly every customer was eating the 39-year-old chef and owner Joshua Pinsky’s oven-warm loaf, served with butter and anchovies.

title: In California’s Heartland, Some Latino Immigrants Back Trump’s Border Stance
description: When José Pérez Gómez came from Mexico more than 25 years ago, he scraped together money by selling handmade furniture on the streets of Fresno, Calif. Eventually, he turned that hustle into a full-fledged brick-and-mortar business, which allowed him to raise a family and send two daughters to college.

title: Inside the World of Competitive ‘Tablescaping’
description: If you look to the Los Angeles County Fair’s annual tablescaping competition for a little place-setting inspiration, you may find, among other eccentricities, a giant handmade squid pressed against a floating submarine porthole, a fake urn for a fictitious dead cat, a dozen or so dolls and the endless glittering frills of tinsel.

title: Can Tisch Put Her Stamp on the N.Y.P.D.?
description: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the issues facing Jessica Tisch as she moves from sanitation commissioner to police commissioner. We’ll also find out what the Columbia University football team did for the first time since John F. Kennedy was in the White House.

title: An I.V.F. Mix-Up, a Shocking Discovery and an Unbearable Choice
description: In the days after Daphna Cardinale delivered her second child, she experienced a rare sense of calm and wonder. The feeling was a relief after so much worrying: She and her husband, Alexander, had tried for three years to conceive before turning to in vitro fertilization, and Daphna, once pregnant, had frequent and painful early contractions. But now, miraculously, here was their baby, their perfect baby, May, with black hair plastered on her head. (May is a nickname that her parents requested to protect her privacy.)

title: I’ll Never Forget What Kennedy Did During Samoa’s Measles Outbreak
description: In November 2019, when an epidemic of measles was killing children and babies in Samoa, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — who in recent days became Donald Trump’s pick to lead the department of Health and Human Services — sent the prime minister of Samoa a four-page letter. In it, he suggested the measles vaccine itself may have caused the outbreak.

title: How Universities Cracked Down on Pro-Palestinian Activism
description: Colleges and universities have tightened rules around protests, locked campus gates and handed down stricter punishments after the disruptions of pro-Palestinian demonstrations and encampments last spring.

title: A Nobel Laureate’s Journals Offer Much Color but Little Drama
description: Is Orhan Pamuk’s “Memories of Distant Mountains: Illustrated Notebooks, 2009-2022” the most embarrassing book published in modern times by a recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature?

title: The Comedy of Pain, and Korean Food
description: The comedian Youngmi Mayer didn’t mean to bring a cockroach into a downtown Manhattan food hall.

title: Easing the Biodiversity Crisis One Flowerpot at a Time
description: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Giving Guide 2024. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

title: Donald Trump Will Do Nothing to Bring Back Our Dying American Dream
description: Donald Trump got lucky in his first term. When he arrived, inflation was low, unemployment was falling, and growth was steady. He applied a bit of juice via his large regressive tax cut, and the economy accelerated without triggering inflation. In retrospect, his term was a bit like a speeding car that got away with it.

title: What Makes You Cry?
description: You’re watching a romantic comedy and the protagonist finally finds true love.You’re embarrassed by your teacher in front of the entire class.Your younger sibling wins the state athletics championship against all odds.Your pet dies.

title: How Trump Could Upend Electric Car Sales
description: Many car buyers have come to rely on a $7,500 federal tax credit on electric vehicles to soften the blow of their high prices. But those credits could disappear after President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office, leading to an almost immediate drop in sales of the cars and trucks.

title: $1.5 Million Homes in California
description: This recently renovated, three-bedroom, two-bathroom house sits in the hills of Los Angeles’s Mount Washington neighborhood, 15 minutes north of downtown. The adjoining lot is included as part of the sale, allowing for the addition of another structure.

title: The Defeat of Kamala Harris Is Not the End of the Story
description: Just how long do you think it will be before we get a woman president?

title: I’m a Food Editor. I Hate Thanksgiving Dinner.
description: Margaux Laskey, an associate editor at New York Times Cooking, has a surprising confession: She doesn’t like Thanksgiving dinner. After days of effort, she finds the final product bland and boring. “I love gratitude and thankfulness, but I’m grateful I don’t have to eat turkey if I don’t want to,” she says. In this episode, she shares ways to celebrate Thanksgiving — no cooking required.

title: How Do I Balance Being Fashionable With Being Professional?
description: This is a misinterpretation of the situation, a sort of inane inverse of the adage that children should be seen and not heard. It suggests that adults should be heard but not seen, and in an increasingly visual world, that idea is a nonstarter.

title: What if It Gets Really Bad? Four Columnists Debate Trump’s Approach to Power.
description: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Jamelle Bouie, Ross Douthat, M. Gessen and Lydia Polgreen about Donald Trump’s preparations for a second term and what they signal about America’s future.

title: How Democrats Lost Their Base and Their Message
description: It has long been clear that the rise of Donald J. Trump meant the end of the Republican Party as we once knew it.

title: Trump’s Judicial Hero Would Have Hated His Recess Appointments Plan
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has singled out one former member of the Supreme Court as his judicial north star: Justice Antonin Scalia, a giant of the conservative legal movement who died in 2016.

title: An Emerald Taken From Brazil Decades Ago May Soon Be Returned
description: Tales have been told for years about the famed 836-pound emerald believed to be worth up to $1 billion: that it survived a panther attack, that it survived the floods of Hurricane Katrina, that the gem may be cursed.

title: Philippines President Slams Vice President’s Assassination Plot
description: President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. of the Philippines said on Monday that he was taking seriously “deeply concerning” threats that had been made against him, days after his vice president said she had arranged for an assassin to kill Mr. Marcos if she were murdered.

title: On the Outskirts of Beirut, a Crowd Watches the War, and Waits for Its End
description: The crowds gather every evening on a scenic hillside on the outskirts of Beirut. Young men, old couples and local journalists, all drawn by the unobstructed view of the Dahiya, the cluster of neighborhoods south of Beirut that has been pummeled by Israeli airstrikes over the past two months.

title: Netanyahu Signals Openness to Cease-Fire With Hezbollah, Officials Say
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has indicated he is open to a cease-fire in the yearlong conflict with Hezbollah, as U.S. officials pressured him to finalize a deal before Thanksgiving, according to two Israeli officials briefed on his thinking.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,256
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 534
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: The Trump Transition’s Secret Funding, and a Campus Crackdown
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: A Sudden Escalation in Ukraine Before Trump Takes Office
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has promised a radically different approach to foreign policy from that of the Biden administration. In Ukraine, he has pledged to end the war in a day.

title: Storm Bert Batters Britain, Leaving at Least 3 Dead
description: Widespread travel disruption took place across Britain on Monday as a result of Storm Bert, which pounded the country with a deluge of rain and fierce winds over the weekend.

title: A Climate Change
description: Some of Donald Trump’s first steps on climate change when he enters the White House will send a message that the federal government no longer cares about the issue. He will pull out of the Paris Agreement. Allies say he’ll strip the phrases “climate change,” “clean energy” and “environmental justice” from every agency website.

title: The Bessent Bounce — Markets Cheer Trump’s Treasury Pick
description: Stocks and bonds are rising on Monday, and the dollar is down. On the first trading day since Donald Trump chose the billionaire financier Scott Bessent as his pick for Treasury secretary, investors seem to be signaling they like the choice.

title: Barbara Taylor Bradford, Whose Sagas Were Best Sellers, Dies at 91
description: Barbara Taylor Bradford, one of the world’s best-selling novelists, who captivated readers for decades with chronicles of buried secrets, raging ambitions and strong women of humble origins rising to wealth and power, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Newsom Challenges Trump on Electric Vehicle Tax Credits
description: California will step in and provide rebates to eligible residents who buy electric vehicles if President-elect Donald J. Trump ends the $7,500 federal E.V. tax credit, Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Monday.

title: Can You Find The 13 Hidden Book Titles in This Text Puzzle?
description: This very short story hides the titles of 13 popular books published in the first decade of the 21st century. Dive in and see if you can find them all — and get an instant reading list at the end.

title: Regulator Sues Anti-Police Activist Who Spent Charity Funds on Himself
description: The District of Columbia’s attorney general on Monday sued an activist known for his calls to abolish the police, saying that he diverted $75,000 from a charity to pay for mansion rentals, a trip to Cancún and designer clothes.

title: Macy’s Discovers Employee Hid Millions in Delivery Expenses
description: Macy’s said on Monday that an employee had “intentionally” misstated and hidden up to $154 million in delivery expenses over the past few years, forcing the retailer to delay a much-anticipated earnings report that Wall Street uses to gauge the strength of holiday shopping.

title: Ex-Dancer Accuses Shen Yun of Forced Labor and Trafficking in Lawsuit
description: A former dancer for Shen Yun Performing Arts, the prominent music and dance company of the Falun Gong religious movement, filed a lawsuit on Monday accusing the group and its leaders of trafficking vulnerable children to work for little to no pay.

title: Dating App Fatigue? In Vermont, Personal Ads Still Thrive.
description: Katie Flagg moved to Vermont when she was 18 to attend Middlebury College and fell in love at first sight — with the state. But after she graduated and moved to a farmhouse in the middle of rural Addison County, she had a sudden pang of doubt: Would she live there alone forever?

title: Israeli Strikes Destroy Buildings Near Beirut
description: Israel hit buildings in the Dahiya area south of Beirut, Lebanon, as it continued a heavy exchange of fire with Hezbollah.

title: U.K. Man Fighting for Ukraine Is Said to Be Captured in Russia
description: Russian forces in the country’s Kursk region have captured a British man who volunteered for the Ukrainian Army, Russia’s state news agencies reported, in what would likely be the first case of a Westerner detained on Russian soil while fighting for Ukraine.

title: If My Dying Daughter Could Face Her Mortality, Why Couldn’t the Rest of Us?
description: The first week of March 2022, I flew to Miami with my 13-year-old daughter, Orli; her 8-year-old sister, Hana; and my partner, Ian. We were, by all appearances, healthy. Robust, even.

title: Steel Maker ThyssenKrupp to Slash 11,000 Jobs in Germany
description: ThyssenKrupp, the largest steel maker in Germany, said Monday that it would eliminate up to 11,000 jobs by 2030, a decision that comes as the country struggled to overcome economic weakness that has hindered growth for nearly two years.

title: Can Wall Street Billionaires Deliver on Trump’s Blue-Collar Promise?
description: When Donald J. Trump first ran for the White House in 2016, his closing campaign advertisement lamented the influence of Wall Street in Washington, flashing ominous images of big banks and the billionaire liberal philanthropist George Soros.

title: Trump’s Middle East Envoy Has Prior Ties to Oil-Rich Nations There
description: Steven Witkoff, the billionaire New York real estate executive whom President-elect Donald J. Trump has named as his special envoy to the Middle East, was in a jam.

title: Cheese Dreams Live Up to Their Name
description: And seemingly without warning, Thanksgiving is only three days away. I’m not going to stress you out with a checklist of things to do for the great feast (except for a little reminder to defrost your turkey if you haven’t already). Instead, I’m going to focus on getting you fed for all the other meals during this frantic week. Just because you’re cooking turkey on Thursday doesn’t mean you have to skip dinner tonight.

title: ‘DNA Typewriters’ Can Record a Cell’s History
description: Shortly after conception, a fertilized egg divides, becoming two. Then each of those cells splits, becoming four, and on and on. Over time, those lineages of cells grow distinct, giving rise to all the different organs and tissues in the human body and comprising as many as 36 trillion cells.

title: Democrats Rush to Regroup in the Southern Battlegrounds
description: For some Democrats in the South, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victories in Georgia and North Carolina this month crystallized a nagging fear that the inroads they had made in these presidential battlegrounds could be dismissed as a fluke.

title: What’s Going on With All of These Food Recalls?
description: There has been a barrage of bad news about food lately. Ten people died after eating Boar’s Head deli meat in a listeria outbreak that hospitalized dozens of others. One person has died and more than 100 people have been sickened in an E. coli outbreak linked to onions served on McDonald’s Quarter Pounders. This month, there has been a food recall nearly every day.

title: Kitchens Are a Force for Social Change
description: On the outskirts of Austin, Texas, a place called Community First! Village has become pivotal to the city’s plans for addressing homelessness in the city.

title: Overcoming Obesity, With Diet and Physical Education
description: To the Editor:

title: The ‘Rocket Docket’ Judge Who Will Decide the Fate of Google’s Ad Technology
description: During a trial in a Virginia courtroom in September over Google’s dominance in advertising technology, concepts and phrases like a “second-price auction," “demand-side platforms” and “header bidding” repeatedly came up.

title: An A.I. Granny Is Phone Scammers’ Worst Nightmare
description: Daisy Harris likes birds — there’s one outside her window. Her cat is named Fluffy, and she’d love to tell you about her knitting hobby. She likes tea and biscuits. And she just can’t seem to figure out this internet thing.

title: In Haiti, a Grim Barometer: Even United Nations Workers Are Fleeing
description: A United Nations helicopter has been buzzing nonstop for days over Haiti, as the U.N. starts to draw down its personnel in Port-au-Prince, evacuating 14 people at a time in chopper rides.

title: How Much Thanksgiving Turkey Should I Buy Per Person?
description: On Thanksgiving, leftovers are natural and expected — even hotly anticipated. But striking that balance between extra and way too much can be difficult.

title: Storm Bert Causes Flooding Across Britain and Ireland
description: Heavy weekend rain and strong winds brought in by Storm Bert caused widespread flooding and travel disruptions across Britain and Ireland, and killed at least three people in England and Wales.

title: Kendrick Lamar Heads Back to His Comfort Zone on ‘GNX’
description: Every so often, Kendrick Lamar steps into the present.

title: New Mexico City to Pay $20 Million to Family of Woman Shot by Police
description: The city of Las Cruces, N.M., has agreed to pay $20 million to the family of a 45-year-old woman who was shot and killed by a city police officer, settling a lawsuit that highlighted the state’s persistently high rate of police killings.

title: U.A.E. Arrests 3 Uzbeks Linked to Murder of Israeli Rabbi
description: The United Arab Emirates on Monday announced the arrests of three Uzbek nationals in connection with the kidnapping and murder of an Israeli-Moldovan rabbi, an attack that raised alarm over the safety of the small Jewish community in the country.

title: Republicans Freak Out Over Trump’s Choice for Labor Secretary
description: It might be the most shocking news yet to come out of this roller-coaster of a transition: After weeks of choosing cabinet secretaries who seem determined to destroy the agencies they will lead, Donald Trump announced the choice of a secretary of labor whom many American workers actually like.

title: Do You Use Online Betting Markets? Tell Us About It.
description: After a Supreme Court case in 2018 opened the door to legal sports gambling, millions of Americans began using sports betting platforms like DraftKings and FanDuel. During the election season, many also placed bets on political outcomes using platforms like PredictIt, Kalshi and Polymarket.

title: Bishop T.D. Jakes Recovering From ‘Health Incident’ During Sunday Sermon
description: Bishop T.D. Jakes, the Dallas-based megachurch pastor, was recovering after he experienced an unspecified “health incident” during his Sunday sermon, according to his church.

title: Devoted Aide Who Keeps Good News Flowing Will Follow Trump to the White House
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has always demanded loyalty from his aides, but few have answered the call quite like Natalie Harp.

title: Thousands Defy Pakistan Crackdown to Rally for Imran Khan’s Release
description: Thousands of supporters of jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan defied a government lockdown and violent police opposition to march to the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan, on Monday evening and demand his release, the latest escalation of political tensions.

title: The Nosy and Deadly 81-Year-Old With an 8-Year-Old Blackmailer
description: HAVOC (Harper, 242 pp., $30), a deliciously nasty tale of resentment and revenge, is set in a once-fashionable hotel in Luxor, Egypt, where 81-year-old Maggie Burkhardt has grandly taken up residence during the pandemic. Her insatiable need to meddle in the lives of others, often without their knowledge, has already forced her to make exits from 18 previous hotels over five years.

title: ‘Liberated’ From Leadership, McConnell Is Ready to Pick His Own Fights
description: The last time President Donald J. Trump was in the White House, Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who was then the majority leader, played a crucial role in empowering him and pushing through his agenda.

title: Biden Pardons Turkeys for the Last Time as President
description: President Biden appeared for eight minutes on Monday to extend pardons to a pair of Thanksgiving turkeys, with a quick nod to the 77-year-old tradition and a brief moment of reflection to give thanks to the country.

title: Jack Smith Seeks Dismissal of Two Federal Cases Against Trump
description: The special counsel Jack Smith asked two courts on Monday to effectively shut down the federal criminal cases he brought against President-elect Donald J. Trump last year, bowing to a Justice Department policy that says it is unconstitutional to pursue prosecutions against sitting presidents.

title: U.S. Says Google Is an Ad Tech Monopolist, in Closing Arguments
description: Lawyers for the United States on Monday said that Google had created a monopoly with its services to place ads online, closing out an antitrust trial over the company’s dominance in advertising technology that could add to the Silicon Valley giant’s mounting woes.

title: Judge Allows San Jose State Transgender Volleyball Player to Compete
description: A transgender volleyball player at San Jose State University can continue to compete on the women’s team, a judge ruled Monday, despite complaints from other players who object to the participation of an athlete who is transgender.

title: Thousands Demand Imran Khan’s Release in Major Pakistan Rally
description: The capital of Pakistan is under lockdown as thousands of supporters of jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan have marched towards Islamabad to demand his release.

title: Paul Caponigro, Photographer in Love with Nature, Dies at 91
description: In 1967, when the renowned landscape photographer Paul Caponigro was living in Dublin, he learned about a herd of white deer in nearby County Wicklow. Intrigued, he asked a man who worked on a large estate there if he could get his dog to chase the deer in and out of a forest.

title: Who Needs Congress When You Have Cameo?
description: Recently out of politics? Have some time on your hands and want to make a few bucks?

title: Nan Goldin Challenges Germany on What Artists Can Say About Israel
description: The artist and activist Nan Goldin makes no secret of her views about Israel and the wars in Gaza and Lebanon.

title: Widespread Microsoft Outage Takes Email and Videoconferencing Offline
